posts.text:
Over the years, I‚Äôve found that seniority at work isn‚Äôt about age, experience, tenure or position.

Seniority at work is simply about navigating different organisational intricacies shrewdly and delivering results inspite of these organisational intricacies.

Here is what that definition truly implies about a person:

1. They are fluent in the "Shadow Structure"

They don't just read the organizational chart; they read the room. 

They understand that every company has two operating systems:

- The Official Structure: Titles, policies, reporting lines, and strategy decks.

- The Human Structure: Trust networks, informal influence, historical loyalties, and unspoken veto power.

Seniority is the ability to get the official work done by masterfully navigating the human structure.

2. They are pragmatists, not idealists

A less senior person might say, "The process says we need to do it this way, so we're stuck." 

A senior person sees the process not as a cage, but as a suggestion. 

They accept that "organisational intricacies" (politics, bureaucracy, red tape etc.) are a permanent feature of the landscape, not a bug to be fixed. 

They stop wishing for a perfect system and start winning within the imperfect one.

3. They are defined by "In spite of"

This is the most critical part of this thinking. 

Navigating intricacies shrewdly could just describe a skilled politician. But coupling it with delivering results separates the value-creators from the power-players.

- The politician navigates intricacies to elevate their own status.

- The senior professional navigates intricacies to deliver outcomes despite the friction.

In short:

A senior professional is someone who has mastered the art of execution despite entropy. 

He or she is a pragmatic realist who uses their understanding of the human and systemic landscape as a tool to build a path to the finish line.

posts.text:
Feb 11th 2001 - exactly 25 years ago - was the first day of a 3-day meeting at the Snowbird ski resort in Utah that gave birth to the Manifesto for Agile Software Development.

Like all important documents, most folks who think they know what it says don't appear to have actually read it.

There's no mention of "sprints", or "story points", or "user stories", or "build pipelines" or "Kanban boards" or any of the other details of specific Agile methodologies. The Manifesto isn't a "how-to" guide. It's a "why-to" guide.

It lays out a set of values and principles for teams who wish to be more responsive to changing user and business needs, through continuous learning and adaptation in a highly people-centric - and especially customer-centric - process.

On the front page of the manifesto's website, it states:

"We are uncovering better ways of developing software by doing it and helping others do it.

Through this work we have come to value:

- Individuals and interactions¬†over processes and tools
- Working software¬†over comprehensive documentation
- Customer collaboration¬†over contract negotiation
- Responding to change¬†over following a plan

That is, while there is value in the items on the right, we value the items on the left more."

The values and principles of Agile Software Development describe what it is like to *be* agile (with a small 'a'). We do not "do" agile. We do not "adopt" agile. We do not "implement" agile.

We *become* agile.

The manifesto itself is, of course, a laudable but compromised attempt to bring multiple iterative and "lightweight" development methodologies - different "brands" - under one banner.

One of those brands came to dominate in the minds of software developers. 

Another came to dominate in the minds of managers and executives, and ultimately came to dominate economically. This was a mistake.

"Agile Software Development" is doing software development in an agile way. It's not a management thing. 

Agile teams are self-organising, because putting decision-making power where (and more importantly, when) decisions need to be made - and therefore understood - is one of the keys to unlocking greater agility. A chain of command almost always becomes a serious bottleneck.

The other key message that got lost in translation is the need for strong technical chops. Teams who can't deliver rapidly, reliably and sustainably get micromanaged, and that ends their experiment in agility.

Without development teams with strong technical *discipline* who are empowered to make decisions, Agile Software Development becomes little more than Agility Theatre. And that's the reality for the majority of teams today - command-and-control waterfall development wearing an Agile Halloween costume.

I recommend reading the manifesto again (or for the first time). Perhaps do it as a team. Maybe talk about how the values and principles could or are helping, and identify where your organisation might just be play-acting

‚ÄúThe only way to go fast, is to go well.‚Äù - Robert C. Martin, "Clean Architecture"

In today‚Äôs fast moving (technology) world, success is not only about speed, innovation or the right product-market fit, it is also about standing on the right foundation.

A strong cloud foundation isn‚Äôt a ‚Äúnice to have.‚Äù 

It‚Äôs the difference between an organisation that moves fast with confidence and one that struggles with security gaps, inconsistent environments, and operational friction.

Here‚Äôs a "short" sales pitch why a cloud foundation matters:

üîí Security by Default
A well‚Äëdesigned foundation enforces guardrails from day 1; identity, networking, logging, encryption, governance. Instead of reacting to risks, teams start from a secure baseline and build upward.

üéØ Consistency Across Environments
When environments are created through standardised landing zone templates and policies, you avoid configuration drift. Dev, test, and production behave predictably, lowering operational risk and simplifying troubleshooting.

‚öôÔ∏è Scalability & Automation
A cloud foundation forces automation-first practices: Infrastructure as Code, CI/CD pipelines, micro‚Äësegmented networks, and controlled service enablement. This turns the cloud into a repeatable, scalable platform instead of a collection of hand-crafted setups.

üìâ Reduced Cost & Waste
Clear governance and cost controls, from budgets to approved services, keep cloud spend intentional rather than accidental. A good foundation doesn‚Äôt limit innovation; it channels it efficiently.

üë©‚Äçüíª Empowered Teams
When platform capabilities and boundaries are clear, teams can innovate faster. Developers get safe sandbox environments, product teams get clarity on what they can deploy, and security teams get full visibility and trust in the setup.

üåç Compliance Made Achievable
Whether it‚Äôs data residency, auditing, or identity standards, a cloud foundation transforms compliance from a manual burden into an automated design principle.

A cloud foundation isn't just an IT construct, it's an accelerator for innovation, resilience, and trust.

#cloudfoundation #cloudsecurity #cloudresilience #compliance #zerotrust #automation #iac #infrastructureascode

posts.text:
A while back, I was in a later stage interview for a role I was fairly interested in. 

The recruiting manager spent 15 minutes of our 60-minute slot detailing his career, his achievements, and how tremendously well he had done.

That‚Äôs 25% of the available time, time meant for assessing fit, discussing the role, and addressing questions, used for a selfpromoting pitch.

It was an immediate red flag. üö© 

It signaled a leadership style centered on self-promotion over mentorship, and a culture where listening might not be a priority.

I finished the interview professionally, but later excused myself from the process. 

I chose to look for leadership that lifts others up, not just themselves.

The takeaway: 

Interviews are a two-way street. 

They‚Äôre your window into team dynamics and leadership values. 

Pay close attention to how people in power use their time and share the platform.

When someone spends a quarter of an interview selling themselves to you, ask: 

What does that say about their focus? 

Their humility? 

Their capacity to develop others?

Culture fit is about spoken and nonspoken signals. 

And sometimes, the signal is a manager who forgets the interview isn‚Äôt about them.

#CareerAdvice #RedFlags #CompanyCulture #InterviewTips #SelfAwareness #ProfessionalGrowth

posts.text:
You can‚Äôt have accountability when decisions are delegated to committees. 

Committees can‚Äôt be held liable, can‚Äôt be held accountable, as they don‚Äôt own or live with consequences of decisions.

Why do companies so often default to committee-based decision-making?

The answer isn‚Äôt simple malice or incompetence. 

It‚Äôs often a well-intentioned response to complex problems:

1. Risk Diffusion: 

In risk-averse cultures, a committee spreads the blame, creating a perceived safety net. It‚Äôs a mechanism for shared organizational protection, however misguided.

2. The Illusion of Buy-in: 

Gathering multiple stakeholders seems like a way to ensure alignment and smoother implementation. The decision may be weaker, but the path to execution appears less rocky.

3. Handling Cross-Functional Complexity: 

When a decision impacts Sales, Marketing, Product, and Finance, who really has "skin in the game"? The committee becomes a proxy for the enterprise's collective skin.

But this comes at a massive cost: slowed velocity, diluted ownership, and mediocre outcomes. 

The committee‚Äô primary incentive shifts from "get it right" to "avoid getting it wrong."

So, what's the alternative?

We shouldn‚Äôt abolish committees entirely, but we must redefine their role. 

They should be used for consultation ONLY, not for decision. 

Their input is vital, but the decision itself must be placed squarely with a named individual.

That individual must have the authority, resources, and, critically, the responsibility for the outcome. 

They have the "skin in the game."

Leaders: your job is to design decision-rights frameworks that mandate single-point accountability. 

Use committees as advisory boards. 

Use RASCI charts to clarify roles. 

Reward decisive ownership, even when it leads to occasional failures, more than you reward flawed consensus.

Because in the end, a single throat to choke is also a single back to pat. 

That‚Äôs where innovation, speed, and true accountability live.

#Accountability #DecisionMaking #Management #CorporateCulture #Execution #SkinInTheGame

posts.text:
You see the red flag üö©, but the team doesn‚Äôt wave it. Why?

One would think having a member of the team not performing or just not conforming as well as the rest would send off immediate red flags to the manager. 

Over the years, I‚Äôve noticed that the flags are all but immediate or very clear.

The team often steps in, overcompensating for the lack of performance, hoping the team member in question would notice and "come to their senses." 

This behavior stems from our nature as social beings, where the desire for group harmony often overrides individual accountability. 

This makes it harder for a manager to course-correct early, rather than later when negative patterns are entrenched. 

This isn't a failure of the team, but a natural human tendency that requires proactive leadership to navigate.

Research into team dynamics gives us the language for what we intuitively observe. 

What I've called "hoping they'll come to their senses" often manifests as "groupthink" - where the drive for consensus and harmony leads to suppressing concerns and avoiding healthy conflict. 

A team‚Äôs "cohesiveness," while usually positive, can become a liability if it prioritizes "we-ness" over addressing performance gaps.

The cost of this quiet compensation is steep: reduced overall productivity, decreased morale, burnout for high performers, and even increased turnover as your best people seek healthier environments.

My experience is that the manager needs to observe team dynamics continuously, ask probing questions, and stay on top of team health to catch outliers early. 

This is constant work. Just because a team reaches a "performing" state doesn't mean it will stay there. New members, changed conditions, and external pressures all shift the dynamics.

Staying present, inquisitive, and available are the key characteristics of a leader who can steer through all types of waters. This isn't micromanagement; it's about creating the conditions for sustainable success.

The most functional teams aren't those without problems; they are the ones with the trust, tools, and leadership to address problems openly and early.

#TeamLeadership #Management #TeamDynamics #PsychologicalSafety #HighPerformingTeams #PeopleManagement #LeadershipDevelopment

Reflecting on 5 Incredible Years at SEB!

Life is made of many stories, and as I prepare to close this chapter (for now at least), I‚Äôve been reflecting on the journey. 

"Two roads diverged in a wood, and I -
I took the one less traveled by,
And that has made all the difference." 
- ‚ÄùThe Road Not Taken‚Äù by¬†Robert Frost

The path was less a straight road and more like a forest hike, navigating internal rules and regulations, layers of technical legacy, ongoing modernization efforts, and complex organizational dynamics.

But the destination was worth every step.
 
In random order, here are some achievements from the past five years:

- Recruiting amazing talent and building high-performing Cloud Foundation and SaaS Integrator teams.

- Building and maintaining highly automated deployment engines for all cloud environments, ensuring consistency, efficiency, and security while allowing development teams to innovate in zero-trust isolation.

- Creating and maintaining a single funnel for all cloud and SaaS onboarding to provide insight, visibility, and compliance.

- Creating insights into the usage of our platforms across a number of KPIs and metrics to both drive product development as well as ensure compliance and security of the platforms.

- Providing virtual tailored classroom trainings on various cloud subjects to thousands of SEB colleagues.

- Taking our cloud platforms through internal approvals to ensure adherence for hosting the highest levels of data criticality, integrity, and availability.

- Scaling from a handful of cloud-first adopters to thousands of monthly active users, thousands of active cloud environments, and a wide array of modern cloud applications delivering 24/7 bank services.

- Ensuring compliance of cloud platforms with financial services regulations across jurisdictions from Asia to the Americas.
 
None of this would have been possible without the absolutely incredible people at SEB, the beating heart of the organization. 

Brave, intelligent, passionate, focused and dedicated. 

So many colleagues became friends, and you are the reason we pulled this through. 

That‚Äôs also why the decision to leave was so difficult. 

However, the next story was simply too hard to say no to. 

Come April, I will be joining a company, I myself have been a dedicated customer of for years, with an inspiring team and a focused mission ahead. More on that later.
 
For the next two months, I‚Äôll be wrapping up, handing over, and of course, enjoying as many Thursday pancakes as possible.
 
#SEB #CloudJourney #LifeatSEB #SEBCloud #SEBTech #DigitalTransformation #FinTech #Gratitude #CareerMove #PlatformEngineering #ZeroTrust #Compliance #Teamwork #NextChapter

posts.text:
In our current era of engineered contentment and digital distraction, Aldous Huxley's Brave New World feels less like speculative fiction and more like a diagnostic manual for the modern age. 

Published in 1932, its central question; wheater perpetual, superficial happiness is worth the sacrifice of human depth, resonates with unsettling precision today. 

From the potent symbolism of Shakespeare, wielded by the so-called "savage," Huxley crafts a timeless critique of a society that trades free thought, tragedy, and truth for a painless, preordained stability.

The novel‚Äôs richest conflict manifests in the character of John, raised on a "Savage Reservation." 

To the "civilized" World State, he is a primitive curiosity. 

Yet, he alone possesses a deep education in the works of Shakespeare, the pinnacle of Western literary civilization. 

His exclamation, "O brave new world, That has such people in't!" borrowed from Miranda in The Tempest, is initially uttered in awe but soon curdles into bitter irony as he witnesses the emotional and spiritual poverty beneath the society's shiny veneer.

This reversal is the novel's masterstroke. 

The "savage" becomes the sole vessel for art, passion, and profound emotion, all qualities systematically eradicated from the "civilized" world in the name of efficiency and control. 

The "civilization" of the World State is built on biological engineering, psychological conditioning, and the abolition of history, family, and diversity. 

True "civilization," as demonstrated by the cultural heritage in Shakespeare's plays, is preserved only among the "savages." 

John‚Äôs identity is forged by Othello, Hamlet, and Romeo and Juliet, plays that explore jealousy, grief, and passionate love, all intense, "unhappy" emotions the World State has pharmacologically and socially eliminated.

The World State‚Äôs stability relies on hypnopaedia (sleep-teaching) and neo-Pavlovian conditioning to mold perfect, compliant citizens. 

Free, critical, or individualistic thought is the system's greatest enemy. 

The genius of Brave New World is that its dystopia is not built on boots and torture chambers, but on pleasure, convenience, and instant gratification. 

The drug soma is the ultimate tool of control, offering "a holiday from the facts". 

Today, we might see its analogues in the endless scroll of social media, algorithmically curated content, and the constant pursuit of optimized living.

The World State‚Äôs mantra of "Community, Identity, Stability" is achieved by erasing individual identity and artistic complexity. 

In an age where uncomfortable emotions are often met with medication or digital distraction rather than introspection or art, Huxley‚Äôs warning is prescient: a world that seeks to eliminate all hardships may eliminate what makes us profoundly human.

The novel challenges us to ask: In our pursuit of a smooth, successful, and "happy" life, are we conditioning ourselves to accept a shallower existence? 

#bravenewworld

posts.text:
Putting "agile fatigue" into context...

I've heard many leaders talk about "agile fatigue" recently, and I want to place it in a broader context. In business, there are always a handful of trends unfolding in parallel. They arrive in waves that take roughly 10‚Äì15 years to form, crest, break, and then recede. Some examples:

-Globalization and offshoring (late 1970s‚Äìearly 2000s)
-Shareholder primacy and financialization (1980s‚Äì2000s)
-Lean and process optimization (1990s‚Äì2010s)
-Agile and digital transformation (mid-2000s‚Äìearly 2020s)
-AI and automation (late 2010s‚Äìpresent)

Within these waves are often sub-waves, niche waves, etc. For example, in the startup niche you see other waves:

-Lean startup and MVP movement (late 2000s‚Äìmid 2010s)
-Growth hacking and hyper-scaling playbooks (early‚Äìlate 2010s)
-Venture-fueled blitzscaling (mid 2010s‚Äìearly 2020s)
-Product-led growth as the default go-to-market model (late 2010s‚Äìpresent)
-AI-native startups and toolchain rebuilding (early 2020s‚Äìpresent)

Or the mini-wave set of:

-Early team-level agile replacing plan-driven delivery (mid-1990s‚Äìearly 2010s)
-Scaling frameworks (early‚Äìmid 2010s)
-Design thinking and UX practices (mid-2010s)
-DevOps and internal platforms (late 2010s)
-Value streams, lean portfolio management, and team topologies (late 2010s‚Äìearly 2020s)
-Product operating models (early 2020s‚Äìpresent)

With every wave, consultancies brew up offerings, co-opt (and hire) from the early majority, sell to the late majority, and eventually make tons of money from the "laggards." The major consultancies began embracing and commercializing Agile well after the methods had become mainstream in tech, roughly in the early to mid-2010s (around 2012‚Äì2018). The pull? Enterprises seeking scaled, enterprise-wide agile transformation services.

-Scaling frameworks emerged around 2011‚Äì2012.
-By the mid-2010s, enterprise agile transformation became a distinct category of consulting offerings (large banks, etc.).
-Major strategy and technology consultancies published agile research and formalized transformation practices by around 2018, reflecting the peak of enterprise agile demand and mainstream adoption.

Fatigue develops when a generation of executives and leaders have heard the same pitches over and over from the same group of consultancies, and eventually ask the sensible question: "OK, show me the results."

The agile community's default answer has often been, "But you never embraced the principles!" But the damage from enterprise offerings, sadly, has already been done, which naturally sends people off looking for other answers.

So whether the fatigue is warranted or not, the damage has been done.

The silver lining is that the really important ideas have taken hold. They aren‚Äôt packageable, but they have permeated how things get done, and what people strive to emulate and achieve.

Next it will be product operating model fatigue...

And "AI operating model" fatigue....

posts.text:
If you‚Äôve ever sat through a strategy meeting that felt more like a vague vision-setting exercise than a concrete plan, ‚ÄúPlaying to Win: How Strategy Really Works‚Äù by former P&G CEO A.G. Lafley and strategy guru Roger L. Martin is worth your time. 

The book delivers a clear, actionable framework for making tough strategic choices. 

However, it often reads like a case study of P&G‚Äôs operating model, which is both a strength and a limitation.

The book‚Äôs central premise is that strategy is choice. 

It‚Äôs not a plan or a vision, but a set of integrated, deliberate decisions about what to do and, crucially, what not to do. 

The authors introduce the ‚ÄúStrategic Choice Cascade,‚Äù a five-question sequence that forces clarity:

1. Winning Aspiration: What does ‚Äúwinning‚Äù truly look like?

2. Where to Play: Which markets, segments, and geographies will you focus on (and where will you not play)?

3. How to Win: What unique value proposition will allow you to beat competitors there?

4. Capabilities Required: What distinctive skills, activities, and systems are needed to deliver on your ‚Äúhow to win‚Äù?

5. Management Systems: What structures, processes, and metrics will support and measure execution?

This cascade is a powerful tool for cutting through strategic ambiguity. 

The book reinforces that a modest aspiration often leads to mediocrity, while focus, born from clear choices, is a crucial winning attribute.

The book also identifies six common strategy traps, which indicate fundamental flaws in strategic thinking. 

- The Do-It-All Strategy: Trying to pursue every opportunity, making everything a priority, and diluting resources. This is the core failure to make explicit choices.

- The Something-for-Everyone Strategy: Attempting to capture all customer, channel, or geographic segments at once, resulting in a muddled value proposition.

 - The Don Quixote Strategy: Attacking the strongest competitor head-on in their core market ("walled cities") without a realistic chance to win.

- The Waterloo Strategy: Starting conflicts on multiple fronts with multiple competitors simultaneously, guaranteeing a losing battle.

- The Dreams-That-Never-Come-True Strategy: Having lofty mission statements that never translate into concrete choices about where to play, how to win, or the required capabilities and systems.

- The Program-of-the-Month Strategy: Constantly shifting initiatives or settling for a generic industry strategy that makes you indistinguishable from competitors.

‚ÄúPlaying to Win‚Äù is a valuable read for executives and strategists in established, product-driven companies who need a disciplined approach to focus and resource allocation. 

However, entrepreneurs, digital innovators, or those in highly fluid industries may find the examples less recognisable. For them, the book is best read as a primer on strategic logic rather than a literal playbook.

#Strategy #BookReview #PlayingToWin #BusinessStrategy #ProcterAndGamble #RogerMartin #AGLafley

posts.text:
A number of years ago, in a new role, I was trying to understand our goals. 

I asked a colleague two simple questions: 

"Who do we benchmark our progress against? How do we know if we're doing better or worse?"

His reply was instinctive and, on the surface, logical: "We benchmark our progress against our closest competitors." 

He meant other similarly-sized companies in our industry, selling similar things to similar audiences.

My response caught him off guard: 

"Ah, so we're benchmarking against other dinosaurs. As I recall, all dinosaurs died out at the same time."

He was understandably taken aback, so I had to explain.

What I meant was this: 

benchmarking solely against your immediate industry rivals is a form of strategic myopia. 

It ensures you're only ever incrementally better, or worse, within a paradigm that may itself be heading for extinction. 

You learn to run faster in a race that might be irrelevant, while completely missing the meteor headed your way - the disruptor from another sector, the shifting customer behavior, the new business model that redefines "value."

The real question isn't just "Are we better than our competitors?" 

It's "Are we creating value for the customers we have, and the customers we want to have?"

Instead of just looking sideways at your direct competitors, you must:

1. Look Forward: 

Benchmark against the companies winning in the customer segments you aspire to serve.

2. Look Sideways: 

Benchmark against companies renowned for excellence in a specific function you're transforming (e.g., benchmark your logistics against Amazon, your customer service against Disney, your design against Apple).

3. Look at the Outcome: 

Customers don't compare you just to your industry. They compare their experience with you to their last best experience with any company. Is your digital onboarding as smooth as your customer's favorite app? Is your service as empathetic as a great hotel chain?

The goal isn't to be the best-looking dinosaur in the valley. 

It's to evolve your company and the people in it, into something that thrives in the new reality.

The only way to win is to be better, not by settling for "slightly better than our closest competitors," but by being objectively excellent in the eyes of the people that matter most: your (future) customers.

How do you avoid "dinosaur benchmarking"? 

Who do you look to outside your industry for inspiration?

posts.text:
Have you ever finished a quarterly planning session, gone back to your day-to-day, and just hoped nothing would change?

You pray the plan holds, the team stays focused, and priorities stay put.

But life happens.

Urgent asks appear.

Estimates shift. 

Things don‚Äôt go as planned.

And one thing is certain: you can‚Äôt just wait until the next planning cycle to deal with change.

So what works?

For us, it‚Äôs transparency, visibility, and a clear decision funnel.

We created a single, living page that lists our key deliveries in priority order for the coming quarters.

- The nearer the quarter, the clearer the deliverables, commitments and other metadata about the task.

- Each priority is paired with why it matters and which customer it serves.

- This page is open to everyone in the company.

This isn‚Äôt just a text heavy roadmap, it‚Äôs a communication tool.

It shows why we can‚Äôt simply ‚Äúsqueeze in‚Äù every urgent request. 

It aligns the team around common goals, not the loudest voice in the room.

And when change is needed?

We have a funnel attached to the page. 

Any new request or shift in priorities goes through a structured assessment:

Should we 

‚úÖ Work on it now if it really is a critical priority, and what may need to be pushed forward.

‚úÖ Backlog it in case it can wait a while longer.

‚úÖ Decline or redirect it in case the ask doesn‚Äôt support the strategy or is better served by some other team. 

We review regularly, every few weeks.

Since starting this, we‚Äôve become more disciplined, kept customers and stakeholders much easier in the loop, and managed expectations far better.

How do you keep priorities aligned when change inevitably hits?

#QuarterlyPlanning #ProductManagement #TeamAlignment #Prioritization #Roadmapping #Agile #StakeholderManagement #Transparency #ProductLeadership

posts.text:
I just finished listening to Orwell‚Äôs ‚Äô1984‚Äô. As dystopian books go, this is the ultimate reference on dystopia.

Its power isn‚Äôt just in its bleakness, but in its chilling familiarity. 

Orwell gives us an incredibly dark world of eternal wars between three hemispheres, one-party rule that cannot be questioned, and disinformation and surveillance abound.

The protagonist, Winston Smith, begins a silent rebellion in his own head. 

Against the party, society, and Big Brother, he stumbles upon the love of his life, Julia. 

In this horrendous world of rations, doublespeak, and hate weeks, a spark ignites in his body and soul.

Their rebellion is intimacy itself. 

In a place where, as Orwell writes, ‚ÄúThe choice for mankind lies between freedom and happiness and for the great bulk of mankind, happiness is better,‚Äù they choose freedom. 

Only briefly.

As they are inevitably caught, the only thing keeping Winston through torture is the idea of her. 

He doesn‚Äôt fully cave until he‚Äôs forced to confront his greatest fear. 

In the end, after their release, they meet - broken, physically and mentally, robbed of the last bright thing they clung to.

He no longer could love her. 

Instead ‚ÄúHe loved Big Brother.‚Äù 

It‚Äôs definitely not a happy book. 

But that‚Äôs why it feels all the more pressing today. 

It‚Äôs less a prophecy and more a stark, eternal warning about the mechanics of power: autocratic rulers, polarized thoughts, divided societies, and the erosion of truth.

The book‚Äôs final terror isn‚Äôt just the triumph of the state, but the systematic dismantling of the human spirit - the victory of a power that demands not just obedience, but sincere, unquestioning love for one‚Äôs own oppression.

All the more today, 1984 remains the ultimate primer on the absolute extremes of unchecked control. 

It asks the question we must continually answer: 

what are we willing to see, to say, and to remember?

#Orwell #NineteenEightyFour #Dystopia #CriticalThinking #Literature

posts.text:
Remember the '90s, dial-up modems, and the brilliant chaos of Westwood‚Äôs Command & Conquer Red Alert?

For a strategy buff like me, it was a perfect balance of play: the powerhouse Soviets with their temperamental super-weapons, the high-tech Americans, and the exotic, futuristic Europeans. 

Three distinct factions, shifting alliances, and a tense, even-matched stalemate. It was a fantastic diversion.

Today, that fictional world feels less like a pastime and more like a disconcerting mirror. 

The clear, ideological divisions of the 20th century have fragmented into a new, fluid landscape of hemispheric influence. 

The old, often steadfast loyalties are increasingly replaced by a transactional, opportunistic mindset. 

It‚Äôs a global arena where today‚Äôs ally can be tomorrow‚Äôs adversary, and principles can seem secondary to pragmatic deals.

It‚Äôs hard not to recall Orwell‚Äôs 1984, not for its surveillance state alone, but for its chilling depiction of perpetual, realigned conflict. 

Oceania, Eurasia, and Eastasia in a constant dance of shifting hostilities and convenient pacts: ‚ÄúThe enemy of my enemy is my friend‚Äù until they aren‚Äôt. 

Orwell wrote of a world where ‚Äúthe war is not meant to be won, but to be continuous.‚Äù 

While we‚Äôre not there, the specter of continuous, managed rivalry, fought in economic, cyber, and informational spheres, feels more plausible than it has in decades.

This isn‚Äôt just a theoretical concern for hobbyists. 

It‚Äôs the framework of the world we are building now, and the one we will leave to the next generation. 

The question it forces upon us is profound: in a landscape defined by transaction over trust, and influence over alliance, how do we anchor our shared humanity and collective security?

As Yeats warned in another era, ‚ÄúThings fall apart; the centre cannot hold.‚Äù 

It feels imperative that in our professional spheres, whether in tech, policy, business, or education, we champion the ‚Äúcentre‚Äù: the enduring values of transparency, genuine partnership, and long-term stability over short-term gain.

Because the game we‚Äôre now in has no power off button.

#Geopolitics #Future #Strategy #History  #CommandAndConquer #GlobalAffairs #NextGeneration #Reflection

posts.text:
Embracing Change in IT: How to "Kill Your Darlings" Without Casualties

We‚Äôve all been there. 

In IT, our ‚Äúdarlings‚Äù aren‚Äôt just personal preferences; they‚Äôre deeply held convictions about say Linux distros, Kubernetes flavors, cloud providers, or observability stacks. 

They represent expertise, invested time, and often, professional identity.

So, how do you lead a change or consolidation journey when it requires people to rethink and relinquish these ‚Äùdarlings‚Äù?

It‚Äôs one of the hardest parts of transformation.

Recently discussed this, and my take is that you can‚Äôt just mandate a ‚Äúbetter‚Äù tool or platform. 

The goal isn‚Äôt to win an argument, but to build shared understanding.

A method that usually works is to move the conversation from opinion to collective evaluation. 

As a team:

1. List all options (the incumbent darling included).

2. Collectively define the criteria that matter most now; cost, scalability, security, skill availability, future roadmap etc. 

3. Weight those criteria based on strategic goals.

4. Evaluate objectively against the weighted framework.

This process isn‚Äôt about proving someone wrong. 

It‚Äôs about transparently aligning on what ‚Äúright‚Äù looks like for the organization going forward. 

Not everyone will walk away in full agreement, but they can understand why the decision was made. 

The respect and inclusivity of the process builds the psychological safety needed to adopt the change.

Ultimately, killing darlings isn‚Äôt about destruction; it‚Äôs about making room for what serves the team and mission best today. 

And sometimes, the most important consolidation isn‚Äôt of tools, but of perspectives.

#ChangeManagement #ITLeadership #DigitalTransformation #TechStrategy #DevOps #TeamCollaboration #KillYourDarlings

posts.text:
Just finished Chris Miller‚Äôs ‚ÄùChip War - The Fight For The World‚Äôs Most Critical Technology‚Äù, and it‚Äôs a book that lingers. 

It's a gripping historical time-lapse of the integrated circuit, its pioneers, and its pivotal moments. 

While written with an American worldview, it offers a sobering look at how silicon became the bedrock of modern power.

The core lesson is that chips are the ultimate power differentiator. 

The book traces how Japan, South Korea, and Taiwan rose by embracing American and European know-how, perfecting it, and eventually leapfrogging their mentors. 

Conversely, the Soviet Union, perpetually a few years behind, lost the arms race partly due to its inability to master chipmaking.

Today, this battle centers on Taiwan and China. 

üáπüáºTaiwan's TSMC isn't just a company; it's a geopolitical linchpin. Consider its staggering dominance:

- Market Power: TSMC holds over 70% of the global foundry market.

- Technology Lead: It produces 92% of the world's most advanced chips and just began mass production of cutting-edge 2nm chips.

- Global Dependence: It supplies everything from Apple's iPhones to Nvidia's AI processors.

Meanwhile, China, as Miller details, has poured billions into achieving "silicon independence," with mixed results. 

Despite massive investment, its self-sufficiency goals remain unmet, and its top foundry, SMIC, holds only a 5.1% market share.

This brings us to the critical question: 

Does TSMC's dominance act as a "Silicon Shield" for Taiwan?

The theory is compelling. 

With over half of Taiwan's chip exports going to China, and a conflict potentially costing the global economy up to $10 trillion, the economic deterrent is immense. The logic is that no one, including China, would risk destroying the world's economic engine.

However, this shield has cracks.

1. Strategic Hedging: The U.S., Japan, and Europe are investing heavily to "de-risk" and build production elsewhere. TSMC itself is building fabs in the U.S. and elsewhere to diversify. Over time, this could dilute the immediate imperative to defend Taiwan's fabs.

2. A "Golden Egg": Conversely, TSMC's priceless technology could be seen by Beijing not as a deterrent, but as a target, the ultimate prize to seize for ‚Äùnational rejuvenation‚Äù.

3. The Innovation Edge: Taiwan plans to keep manufacturing the most advanced chips on home soil to remain indispensable. But if geopolitical pressure forces a faster dispersion of this intellectual crown jewels, the shield weakens.

Continued in the comments üëá

#ChipWar #Semiconductors #Geopolitics #Taiwan #TSMC #Innovation #SupplyChain #Technology #BookReview

üá™üá∫ Europe ‚Äî let‚Äôs get our act together in 2026 üá™üá∫

With 2025 in the rear-view mirror, it‚Äôs time to take in some of the lessons from a watershed year for the world.

Geopolitics have been more prominent than at any time since 1989: the war in Ukraine, a more self-focused United States, the end of globalization as we knew it, and a European Union waking up to a world that requires us to completely rethink competitiveness.

Paradoxically, it is precisely Europe that may now have the greatest opportunity for renewed growth and sustained prosperity. But this will require change. We will need to recalibrate our priorities and embrace reform.

First steps have been taken to strengthen our own security‚Äîbeyond, but not without, existing alliances. This will require a fresh approach to public financing. Only economic growth can provide the resources needed without massively scaling back social welfare and climate ambitions.

Growth will only return if we unleash the full potential of 500 million well-educated, innovative Europeans ‚Äî by reducing overregulation and removing non-tariff barriers that stifle development. The intentions of the new European Commission and many Member State governments point in the right direction, but they still lack concrete measures for less fragmentation and more common market.

As President of EFPIA - European Federation of Pharmaceutical Industries and Associations , I have the privilege of serving one of Europe‚Äôs most important and innovative industries. Our sector embodies what Europe aspires to be: creating high-quality jobs, driving innovation, strengthening industrial presence, boosting exports, and‚Äîabove all‚Äîdelivering better health in an ageing society.

None of this can be taken for granted. Our success cannot rely solely on favourable conditions in the US or China. Europe must strengthen its own market attractiveness for investment in innovation and industrial development. We need faster access to innovative medicines at fair prices, smarter regulation, and the right political incentives.

It is time to get our act together ‚Äî and to see today‚Äôs geopolitical shifts as a unique opportunity to build a stronger, more competitive, and better Europe.

posts.text:
It‚Äôs that time of the year when people list achievements and reflections on the year gone by, on all sorts of social media. 

It‚Äôs easy to get caught in the flywheel and easier still to start comparing and silently competing with everything that‚Äôs being shared.

It‚Äôs just human. 

It‚Äôs one of our most basic traits; to compare ourselves to others, to compete and to imitate.

What‚Äôs being shared, however, is not necessarily the full picture of a year gone by with all its ups and downs. 

It‚Äôs rather a two-dimensional slice of a fruit, as Steve Jobs would put it, probably chosen for its looks but not reflective of the full three-dimensional fruit, with all its dimensions and flavours, both good and bad.

It‚Äôs important to remember here to be kind to oneself, refrain from comparing, and only measure against yourself: how the year prior went and whether you moved forward in your own journey, through both accomplishments and failures.

When I, like everyone else, start reading about and comparing myself with someone else‚Äôs successes, I‚Äôm reminded of an episode ten years ago in Mallorca. 

I took a vacation photo of my son against the azure blue sea (the one below). 

After that perfect, posted Instagram moment, what followed was all but calm and happiness. 

My son had thrown sand in his eyes and wouldn‚Äôt let us wash it out. 

He was shouting in agony; we were panicking in despair. 

Everything was sorted eventually, but to this day, that event reminds me that social media tells a very shallow, two-dimensional version of reality.

There is so much more than meets the eye in every life story, in every feeling, in every experience, nuances that can‚Äôt be digitized or broadcast.

So my promise to myself next year is to do fewer comparisons with others, and many more with myself. 

After all, I don‚Äôt see or understand all the life nuances in others as I do in my own life story.

Here‚Äôs to a 2026 focused on deeper growth, not broader validation. 

To measuring progress by our own standards, and embracing the full, three-dimensional truth of our journeys.

Wishing You and Yours a meaningful and compassionate New Year 2026!

#NewYearReflections #SelfComparison #PersonalGrowth #Mindfulness #SocialMediaAwareness

P.S. Adding another picture of me and my son, now 10 years older. One of the happiest achievements this year for me has been getting the chance to share my passion for running and fitness with him. Not always easy, without conflicts or frustrations, but worth every single second, as it‚Äôs about long term investment in him and our relationship. D.S.

Looking back, a powerful theme connects these diverse titles: 

- Intentionality.

Whether it was McKeown‚Äôs Essentialism and Effortless, Collins on avoiding decline, or Pfeffer‚Äôs 7 Rules of Power, the common thread was clear: 

Success isn‚Äôt about reacting, but about designing deliberate systems and choices.

From Orosz‚Äôs Software Engineer‚Äôs Guidebook to Hohpe‚Äôs Cloud Strategy, the focus was on principled discipline over tactical solutions. 

From Bloom‚Äôs 5 Types of Wealth to Philips‚Äô High on Life, it was about defining what matters beyond the obvious metrics.

Even the fiction (shoutout to Philip K. Dick) and the sharp analysis from Hayden touched on a core idea: 

In an age of noise and distraction, clarity is your most valuable asset.

The books I finished this year (inverse chronological order):

1. The Let Them Theory - Mel Robbins
2. The 5 Types of Wealth - Sahil Bloom

4. Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep? - Philip K. Dick

posts.text:
Jira is a Mirror, Not the Work Itself.

Throughout my career, Jira has been a constant. But I‚Äôve never seen it as the primary place where the actual work gets done.

To me, it‚Äôs a metadata collection - a reflection of the real work that happens outside the ticket. 

Development, ops tasks, support resolutions, incident handling, meeting users‚Ä¶ the value is created elsewhere.

If and when possible, Jira should be fed by the systems where work is performed, and not manually by humans. Why?

1. Human data entry is error-prone for various reasons. 

2. The more complex handling of the tickets and workflows become, the less time is spent on value-adding work, and the more time is lost by ‚Äúfeeding the Jira beast‚Äù with fields, labels, and process overhead.

I often push back hard on unnecessary additions to a simple Jira setup. 

Rarely do they provide real value. 

They just create a more detailed shadow of reality, often at the cost of the reality itself.

A great system should give insight, not impose friction. 

The ticket is not the task; it‚Äôs just a signpost.

‚ÄúThe map is not the territory.‚Äù

#Jira #WaysOfWorking #Productivity #ProcessImprovement

posts.text:
You know that driving, urgent melody you're probably hearing everywhere this month? 

Its story is a powerful lesson in cultural resilience. üéÑüá∫üá¶

This isn't just a Christmas carol. 

It's a Ukrainian anthem that refused to be silenced.

Its journey from a folk chant to a global holiday staple is a story of identity, resistance, and hope.

The melody comes from "Shchedryk," a traditional Ukrainian "winter well-wishing" folk song. 

Its lyrics celebrated a swallow heralding spring and a bountiful new year.

In 1914, in the industrial town of Pokrovsk, yes that Pokrovsk, composer Mykola Leontovych arranged the folk tune for a workers' choir. 

It was first performed in Kyiv in 1916.

Leontovych created "Shchedryk" during a time of intense political struggle. 

In 1919, as Ukraine fought for independence from the nascent Soviet Union, the government had a bold idea: if they couldn't win militarily, they would win culturally.

The newly formed Ukrainian National Chorus was sent on a global diplomatic tour.

Their mission was to promote Ukraine as a sovereign nation with a unique culture. 

"Shchedryk" was a centerpiece of their program.

In 1922, they performed it at a sold-out Carnegie Hall debut, where it was called a "marvel of technical skill".

At that 1922 concert, American conductor Peter Wilhousky (of Ukrainian descent) heard the melody. 

It reminded him of bells, so in 1936 he wrote new English lyrics, creating the "Carol of the Bells" we know today.

Leontovych never saw this global fame. 

For his role in promoting Ukrainian culture, he was assassinated by a Soviet agent in 1921. His music was declared irrelevant for the "Soviet reality".

The same imperial logic that sought to erase Ukrainian culture a century ago persists today. 

The building in Pokrovsk where Leontovych composed "Shchedryk" now sits in a war zone.

Yet, the song endures. 

It is a stunning act of cultural resistance - proof that a melody can become a banner for national identity.

This holiday season, when you hear "Carol of the Bells," remember:

You're not just hearing a Christmas tune. 

You're hearing the unbreakable spirit of a people. 

You're hearing a swallow's promise of spring, composed in defiance, and a echo from a choir that sang for a nation's very right to exist.

#StandWithUkraine #SlavaUkraini #CarolOfTheBells #Shchedryk #History

China is helping Putin in Ukraine!‚ùóÔ∏èWe must stop being naive, not only with the US, but also with China and stop them interfering in our critical infrastructure and exporting our data to boost their own propaganda machines. üá®üá≥

posts.text:
üéâHappy 70th birthday to the European flag üíô‚≠ê
 
üá™üá∫ The European flag was first adopted by the Council of Europe in 1955, long before it became the symbol of the EU. The flag was designed to represent unity, completeness, and harmony among Europe‚Äôs nations. 

‚ú® Why 12? 

It‚Äôs a symbol of completeness: think 12 months in a year, 12 hours on a clock. 

The stars are not country symbols: the design was picked because it wouldn‚Äôt need to change with shifting borders or new members. Decades later, the EU embraced the same flag.

posts.text:
There‚Äôs a recent narrative about the ‚Äúsuppression of free speech,‚Äù in #Europe when compared to the #USA.

It‚Äôs an interesting perspective given that those claiming oppression are often those resistant to listening to any views opposing their worldviews and their beliefs.

Also, those complaining about oppression of #freespeech are often those who try to suffocate, ban, or skew any ideas or points of view that do not align with their own.

This tension lies at the very heart of classical liberal philosophy. 

To move past the slogans and understand the real dilemma, we must return to two thinkers: John Stuart Mill and Karl Popper.

The modern debate is framed by a crucial tension between the near-absolute defense of speech and the necessary defense of a tolerant society from those who would destroy it.

In his 1859 essay On Liberty, Mill built an overwhelming case against silencing any opinion. 

His central argument, often called the "Harm Principle," states that ‚Äúthe only purpose for which power can be rightfully exercised over any member of a civilized community, against his will, is to prevent harm to others‚Äù. 

For Mill, offense, discomfort, or even profound disagreement does not constitute harm.

Writing in the shadow of World War II in The Open Society and Its Enemies (1945), Karl Popper identified a critical limit. 

He formulated the "paradox of tolerance": that unlimited #tolerance must logically lead to the disappearance of tolerance .

Popper‚Äôs argument is nuanced and is often misused. 

He did not advocate for the suppression of merely objectionable ideas. His concern was with ideologies that reject the very framework of rational debate and liberal democracy.

Mill's focus is on the individual's right to speak without state or social interference, based on the fallibility of human judgment and the search for truth.

Popper's focus is on the society's right to survive. He argues a tolerant society must retain the right to defend itself against movements that preach intolerance and would use democratic freedoms to destroy democracy.

As Popper himself cautioned, suppression is ‚Äúmost unwise‚Äù as long as intolerant philosophies can be countered by rational argument and public opinion. 

The line is crossed when such movements ‚Äúbegin by denouncing all argument‚Äù and ‚Äúanswer arguments by the use of their fists or pistols‚Äù.

Legal systems have drawn boundaries that operationalize the principles of preventing harm and protecting societal integrity.

The US approach largely aligns with Mill. Hateful speech is protected unless it falls into a narrow category like incitement. The remedy for bad speech is considered to be more speech.

The European approach is more influenced by Popperian and post-war concerns. Many European nations criminalize hate speech - the public incitement to violence or hatred based on characteristics like race, religion, or nationality - seeing it as a threat to the dignity of others and to social peace.

Continued below.

posts.text:
Imagine if a restaurant behaved like your average product team.

The kitchen is packed. Everyone is moving. Every station is busy. Prep lists are long. Meetings are constant. 

There is always something to do.

Chopping, rearranging, documenting, planning, replating. 

But plates rarely reach customers.

When they do, they‚Äôre late. Or wrong. Or cold. Or oddly disconnected from what the diners said they wanted. Yet the kitchen isn‚Äôt ‚Äúfailing,‚Äù exactly. It never looks like a crisis. No one storms out. No one flips a table. Diners don‚Äôt riot. They just lower their expectations and stop coming back.

Inside the kitchen, though, the staff feels productive. Everyone is exhausted. Everyone is ‚Äúat capacity.‚Äù Everyone can point to a dozen tasks they completed. They can even argue those tasks were important. And in isolation, many of them were.

But restaurants are not judged by how busy the kitchen is. They are judged by how consistently they deliver great food, on time, to the people who ordered it.

Product development is strange because this feedback loop is muted. 

There is no instant revolt. 

A team can be unbelievably heroically busy without producing much that actually moves the needle.

That‚Äôs the trap: in software, effort is easy to generate, activity is easy to justify, and impact is surprisingly easy to avoid.

posts.text:
I‚Äôve always found a deep, personal peace in gardening. 

There‚Äôs something profound about planting a seed, nurturing the fragile sprout, and giving it the conditions to grow stronger each day.

Recently, I realized this isn‚Äôt just a hobby - it‚Äôs the purest metaphor for leadership I know.

The best leadership, like the best gardening, is present but not overbearing. 

It‚Äôs about creating a solid, fertile foundation and then being ready to support when the conditions change. 

You invest effort without always knowing precisely how the harvest will turn out, adapting and trusting the process.

As Nelson Mandela reflected, ‚ÄúLike the gardener, a leader must take responsibility for what he cultivates‚Äù. 

This responsibility isn‚Äôt about control, but about creating the right environment for growth.

Here‚Äôs how the parallel unfolds in practice:

1. Preparing the Soil: The Foundation of Culture

You can‚Äôt grow strong plants in weak soil, and you can‚Äôt develop strong leaders in a poor culture. 

Just as a gardener enriches the earth, a leader‚Äôs first job is to cultivate a foundation of psychological safety and trust. 

This means asking more questions than you answer and treating mistakes as learning opportunities. 

It‚Äôs the essential nutrient for growth.

2. Seeding & Planting: Identifying and Positioning Potential

Every gardener knows you need the right plant for the right spot. 

In leadership, this translates to spotting talent (‚Äúseeds‚Äù) that shows enthusiasm and values, and then intentionally ‚Äúplanting‚Äù people where they will thrive - giving them the sunlight of opportunity and challenge they need to flourish.

3. Pruning & Weeding: The Courage to Focus

Growth often requires removal. 

Pruning isn‚Äôt punishment; it‚Äôs a positive regime to direct energy to the healthiest branches. 

For leaders, this means having the courage to eliminate obsolete tasks, streamline processes, or make tough people decisions to ensure the overall vitality of the team and its mission.

4. Attentive Maintenance: The Daily Work of Care

The glamorous work gets attention, but gardens and teams thrive on consistent, daily care. 

This is the ‚Äúmaintenance‚Äù of leadership: regular one-on-one conversations, providing clear feedback, skill development, and removing bureaucratic ‚Äúweeds‚Äù that stifle innovation. 

It‚Äôs about being attentive - truly tuned in to the needs of your people and the health of the project.

Ultimately, as Susan Collins noted, 

‚ÄúLeaders are like gardeners... we are not only responsible for harvesting our own success but for cultivating the success of the next generation‚Äù.

Our role isn‚Äôt to force growth. 

It‚Äôs to mindfully prepare the ground, provide the right support at the right time, and have the patience to let nature - and human potential - take its course.

#LeadershipDevelopment #GardeningAndLeadership #TeamBuilding #PeopleFirst #PsychologicalSafety #Management

posts.text:
Just finished Mel Robbins‚Äô ‚ÄúThe Let Them Theory,‚Äù and it‚Äôs a jolt of empowering clarity.

In a world obsessed with external validation and over-managing others‚Äô perceptions, Robbins offers a liberating alternative: 

Stop controlling. 

Start living.

The core idea is simple yet profound: 

You can‚Äôt control what other people think, do, or feel. 

The exhausting attempt to do so is a major source of our anxiety and inaction. 

So, instead of trying to force, fix, or convince, you learn to ‚Äúlet them.‚Äù 

Let them think what they want. 

Let them be disappointed. 

Let them handle their own reactions. 

Your energy is then freed to focus on the one thing you truly can control, yourself.

Let me. 

What gives this ‚Äútheory‚Äù heft is how Robbins weaves it with timeless schools of thought:

Stoicism: The clear echo of focusing on your circle of control.

Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT): The practice of identifying and challenging the ‚Äúmind movies‚Äù we create about others‚Äô judgments.

Modern Positive Psychology: The actionable framework for building resilience and self-trust.

This isn‚Äôt about apathy; it‚Äôs about agency. 

It‚Äôs the ultimate playbook for anyone who feels trapped by the "invisible audience"; constantly viewing their choices, career, or life through the imagined lenses of others.

A couple of powerful takeaways:

‚ÄúYour peace is more important than their opinion.‚Äù

And as Robbins puts it: ‚ÄúLetting them be wrong about you is the price of your freedom.‚Äù

It‚Äôs a fast, energetic read that serves as both a permission slip and a practical manual. 

If you‚Äôre ready to trade approval for authenticity and exhaustion for execution, this is your next read.

#TheLetThemTheory #MelRobbins #PersonalDevelopment #Mindset #Leadership #Stoicism #CBT #BookReview #SelfHelp #Empowerment

posts.text:
Europe regulated itself out of the tech game a decade ago. For far too long, we treated regulation as our flagship export, and that‚Äôs precisely where we went wrong. ‚ÄºÔ∏è

üëâüèª I strongly reject the notion that regulation is the best thing the EU has to offer. Europe‚Äôs competitive edge will never come from producing more rules. It will come from enabling innovation, talent, and companies to thrive here rather than elsewhere. 

üëâüèª A crucial part of this conversation is understanding the difference between personal data and non-personal behavior and metadata. Personal data must, without question, be protected. That is a cornerstone of European values, and it should remain so. But when it comes to anonymous behavior and metadata, the EU has become far too cautious, to the point of undermining our own technological progress.

üëâüèª European companies urgently need access to metadata. Policymakers need to understand that it is an essential raw material for all AI testing, training, and deployment. If we continue treating data as a risk rather than an opportunity, we will only deepen our dependency on external technologies and lose the momentum to shape global standards ourselves.

Europe has the talent, the ambition, and the capacity to lead. What we need is an open, harmonized and enabling market, and courage to create a regulatory environment that empowers innovation instead of stifling it. It‚Äôs time to shift from fear to forward motion. ‚òùüèª

posts.text:
I bought a NATO cap a couple of weeks back when I was in #Berlin with my family. 

I was at the #CheckpointCharlie museum giftshop when this cap caught my eye. 

A couple of years ago I would probably not have given it a second glance, but this time it felt right.

I was met by loud protests from the female members of the family, not against the cap or what it stands for, but more worried I‚Äôd upset someone while wearing it. 

Honestly, time for delicacy has since long passed. 

NATO, and even more importantly the pan-#European cooperation in all aspects, is paramount for ensuring continued stability, safety and prosperity of our societies and the world as a whole. 

This is especially true in the current geopolitical climate where autocratic powers seek to undermine the pinnacles of a rules-based world order, individual freedoms, free thought and free speech.

Standing in Berlin, you are standing on ground zero of the #ColdWar. 

The city was not just a symbol of division, but the very catalyst for the alliance whose logo I now wear on the cap. 

In 1948, just three years after the end of World War II, a war that left approximately 36,5 million Europeans dead and cities in ruins, the Soviet Union blockaded all rail, road, and canal access to the Western-controlled sectors of Berlin.

They hoped to force the Allies out. 

Instead, the West responded with the Berlin Airlift, a massive 11-month operation that flew in life-saving supplies, with a plane landing every 30 seconds at the height of the campaign. 

It was a strong evidence of commitment and resolve. 

As one US general noted at the time, remaining in Berlin was seen as "essential to our prestige... a symbol of the American intent".

The success of the airlift solidified the West's resolve. 

Within months, on 4 April 1949, the North Atlantic Treaty was signed, creating NATO. 

Its founding was not solely a military reaction to the Soviet Union, but a broader effort to "deter Soviet expansionism, forbid the revival of nationalist militarism in Europe... and encourage European political integration". 

The principle at its heart is Article 5: "an armed attack against one... shall be considered an attack against them all". 

This principle has ensured the collective defence that has secured #peace for generations.

The words of Dwight D. #Eisenhower, NATO's first Supreme Allied Commander, ring as true today as they did in 1954: 

"We do not keep security establishments merely to defend property or territory or rights abroad or at sea. We keep the security forces to defend a way of life".

That is what this cap represents to me. 

It's not a provocative symbol, but a commitment to the way of life built on those principles of liberty, democracy, and cooperation that were so fiercely defended in the streets of Berlin and have ensured our safety and prosperity ever since.

I will wear it with pride.

#NATO #CollectiveDefence #EuropeanSecurity #BerlinHistory #Geopolitics #TransatlanticAlliance

posts.text:
My journey into #agile started about 10 years ago, roughly at the same time as I took on managing my company‚Äôs #continuousdelivery team. 

Prior to that, I had been a subject matter expert for our many integrations, working closely with customers, business stakeholders, development, and infrastructure teams. 

I had witnessed on my own skin, so to say, the drawbacks of a "throw it over the wall" mindset between departments and teams.

I immersed myself in the #principles, attending #conferences, consuming literature, and always replying to the annual #DORA survey to benchmark our progress.

The agile journeys between different companies and industries are all different but generally follow a few common patterns. 

An initial "all-in" approach, soon replaced with sombreness and contextualisation, and later, if the journey has gone well, fully embedded within the fabrics of the company.

Sometimes, companies employ different frameworks like #SAFe, #LeSS, or even a scaled #Scrum to bridge the gap between current and future state, hoping it might ensure a smoother transition.

However, here lies the danger, in my view.

When agile frameworks are no longer seen as voluntary but prescriptive, one of the core tenants of agile is lost on the altar of standardisation and common recognition: 

üëâ the ability to adapt ways of working to fit the context and constraints in any given situation.

It‚Äôs easy to forget the powerful, simple words of the #AgileManifesto‚Äôs final principle: 

"At regular intervals, the team reflects on how to become more effective, then tunes and adjusts its behavior accordingly."

This isn't a suggestion to be followed only until a framework is in place. 

It's the very heart of agility. 

As Dave Snowden of the #Cynefin #framework famously said, 

"You cannot impose order; you can only disturb the balance and see what emerges." 

Imposing a rigid framework is an attempt to impose order on a complex, human system. 

It might look neat on a PowerPoint slide, but it often stifles the very innovation and adaptability we seek.

Thus, restricting #agility brings unwillingly back the very thing that agile was supposed to do away with: #rigidness and #inflexibility. 

The goal was never to be "Agile" with a capital 'A'. 

The goal was, and is, to be agile i.e. #responsive, #adaptive, and delivering value faster. 

Sometimes that means a team needs to drop a #ceremony, modify a #ritual, or even abandon a framework element that isn't working for them.

True agility isn't about following a map; it's about being a skilled navigator, able to read the terrain and change course when needed.

#Agile #AgileTransformation #BusinessAgility #Scrum #SAFe #Lean #ContinuousDelivery #DevOps #Leadership

üëÜ Europe is finally treating defence as a strategic responsibility. If Europe wants to lead in defence innovation, we need rules that reward speed, excellence and European technological leadership. ‚ùó

Yesterday published the Defence Readiness Roadmap with four flagship capability projects, and the new Military Mobility Package are two important steps for Europe‚Äôs security and industrial resilience. 

üëâ Excellence must guide European defence policy. Defence funding must follow strategic logic, not political distribution formulas. Europe needs an excellence based approach across its defence technology and industrial ecosystem. The principle should be clear: European first. If Europeans finance our security, European industry should benefit.

üìå Threat levels are not equal. Countries closest to conventional military risk must be prioritised. Protecting the Eastern flank protects the whole Union. This is also what I am driving as Rapporteur for the Defence Readiness Omnibus in the European Parliament.

üìå The European Drone Defence Initiative, the Eastern Flank Watch, the European Air Shield and the European Space Shield must move forward on a clear timeline and contribute directly to NATO capability targets. Credible deterrence cannot wait.

‚ùóSchengen for defence is at the core of fast military mobility. Europe cannot defend itself if troops and equipment are stopped at borders. The new Military Mobility Package proposes two things.

üëâ First, for military transport operations, a border crossing would be possible within 72 hours after the receiving Member State has received a notification. 

üëâ Second, a fast crisis framework for priority military movement across the Union, with single contact points and shared transport capacity, would enable the Council to approve a year-long derogation for military mobility in only 48 hours. This is essential for reinforcing our Eastern flank as the United States reduces its permanent footprint.

Ukraine continues to demonstrate how agility and technological innovation shape the modern battlefield, and Europe must learn from that reality. That is why Europe must scale innovation procurement, support dual use development and improve access to finance, so that our startups and industry can deliver the capabilities needed for credible deterrence and for the defence of our Eastern flank.

posts.text:
Did you know the #CIA once wrote the ultimate guide to #workplace #sabotage?

Back in 1944, the OSS (the CIA‚Äôs predecessor) published the Simple Sabotage Field Manual - a handbook for ordinary citizens to discreetly disrupt enemy operations during #WWII.

Here‚Äôs the kicker: many of its tips still sound eerily familiar in today‚Äôs #corporate world. Examples included:

 ‚úÖ Insist on doing everything through ‚Äú#channels‚Äù
 ‚úÖ Refer all matters to #committees for ‚Äúfurther study‚Äù
 ‚úÖ Talk at length about irrelevant issues during #meetings

Sound familiar? 

These tactics were designed to grind wartime organizations to a halt - and yet, decades later, they perfectly describe the behaviors that slow down modern businesses.

Lesson? Whether you‚Äôre leading a team or transforming an enterprise, #agility and #clarity aren‚Äôt just buzzwords - they‚Äôre antidotes to sabotage.

üìú Fun fact: The manual was declassified in 2008 and is freely available online. It‚Äôs a fascinating read if you want to see how timeless #bureaucracy can be!

posts.text:
Security isn't a destination; it's a relentless, high-stakes race. 

In the world of cybersecurity, resting on your laurels is the single greatest risk. 

Believing your current defenses will be sufficient in six months or a year isn't just naive - it's reckless.

Why? Because the bad actors aren‚Äôt taking a break. 

They are innovating, automating, and collaborating. 

To stay ahead, we must continuously push the technological boundaries and move the goalpost forward.

But here‚Äôs the real-world dilemma for most companies: this is incredibly difficult. 

You can‚Äôt just rip and replace core systems every time a new threat emerges. These implementations have multi-year lifecycles, and business continuity is paramount.

So, what‚Äôs the answer? 

Leave the fantasy of an impenetrable, single-layered perimeter.

Embrace Security in Depth: The Strategy of Layered Defense.

The goal isn't to have every layer be the absolute cutting-edge. 

The goal is to have enough robust, overlapping layers so that when one is bypassed, the next one is waiting.

Think of it like a castle:

- The moat (Firewalls, Fine-Grained Network Segmentation)

- The high walls (Endpoint Detection and Response - EDR)

- The gatekeepers (Multi-Factor Authentication - MFA)

- The guards on the walls (Security Monitoring & SIEM)

- The inner keep (Data Encryption & Access Controls)

An intruder might cross the moat and scale the walls, but they will be detected, slowed, and stopped long before they reach the crown jewels.

Look at the recent wave of ransomware attacks. 

Often, the initial breach isn't a zero-day exploit. 

It's a phishing email that bypasses one layer. 

Without subsequent layers, like strict user permissions, application allow-listing, or segregated backups, that single point of failure leads to a full-scale compromise.

As the legendary security expert Bruce Schneier aptly said:

"Security is a process, not a product."

This process is about building a resilient, layered system. 

It‚Äôs about assuming breaches will happen and designing your defenses to contain the damage.

Your Action Plan:

1. Conduct a Layered Audit: Map your security controls. 

2. Prioritize foundational hygiene: Often, the biggest gains come from perfecting the basics, ie patch management, MFA enforcement, and principle of least privilege.

3. Focus on Detection & Response: Invest in capabilities that help you identify and contain a threat after it has breached your perimeter.

Staying ahead isn't about having the one "unbreakable" system. 

It's about building a dynamic, layered defense that ensures an intruder‚Äôs journey is so difficult and noisy that they are either stopped or you find them before they succeed.

#CyberSecurity #DefenseInDepth #CyberResilience #SecurityStrategy #ZeroTrust 

PS Castel Sant'Angelo has had many dramatic security layer changes. From Mausoleum to Papal Fortress to Prison and to Castle. One can literally see these layers of history stacked on top of each other. DS

posts.text:
I'll never forget standing in front of my new Change Management team in 2018. 

I had just taken on the role, managing them alongside my Platform Delivery team, and I asked a seemingly simple question: 

"Have we mapped our internal and external stakeholders?"

"Compliance team," one person added. "Certification team too," said another.

Sure, these teams were crucial. 

Our work was to ensure quality deployments to production for our company's products across a dozen global jurisdictions and countless data centers. 

The list grew. "Well, there are also regulators..." 

Absolutely, they were key stakeholders.

But a critical category was missing.

We had overlooked our primary internal customers: the engineering teams. 

These were the bulk of people actually submitting the change request tickets we reviewed for quality before sending them for approvals. 

We weren't giving our main "customers" sufficient attention, assuming they'd just continue writing tickets as they always had.

This realization was a turning point. 

It got everyone thinking, brainstorming, and reflecting on how to better cater to the sometimes conflicting needs of all our stakeholders.

The result was a simple infographic that clearly explained what we do and, more importantly, why we do it, with the purpose of creating alignment and finally giving all our customers the focus they deserved.

#ChangeManagement #ITIL #ITSM #Compliance #Certification #Engineering
#InternalCustomers #Agile #DevOps #StakeholderManagement #Leadership #ProcessImprovement

posts.text:
The Commission will publish next week its Digital Omnibus - what can we expect: üí°

In general, it‚Äôs positive that the Commission seems to be following through with its commitment to simplification and is willing to address mistakes. The leaked Digital Omnibus looks like a chance to deliver targeted fixes and is a test of whether we can turn a jungle of rules into a framework that actually supports European innovation, jobs and security.

‚òùÔ∏è The question is whether the Council and the Parliament will use it to enable European companies to grow, rather than add yet another layer of complexity.

‚òùÔ∏è Deregulation, as in removing unnecessary, overlapping or confusing obligations is essential for competitiveness, growth and security. But any ‚Äúsimplification‚Äù must not create new uncertainty for those trying to comply.

üìå On the GDPR, clarifying possibilities for data use for AI training with appropriate safeguards is welcome. Reopening the GDPR is a bold move; the real battle will be around Articles 4, 6 and 9. If almost everything continues to be linked to personal data, Europe will struggle to use data at scale to train its own technologies.

üìå On the AI Act Omnibus, the unresolved ‚Äústop the clock‚Äù question has itself become a source of uncertainty. Companies should not be sanctioned for non-compliance with rules that are not technically and legally clear. Next week the Commission needs to provide a clearly defined pause. ‚ùóÔ∏è

üìå One EU-level sandbox is a good idea and should go further, replacing 27 fragmented national approaches. Not aligning sectoral rules with the AI Act is a missed opportunity and goes against the goal of increasing AI uptake and ‚Äúapplying AI‚Äù.

üìå Data Act consolidation and targeted updates to the other three laws can be useful, but must not become a lifeline for four flawed proposals by simply merging them. Fully repealing all four and using a proper digital fitness check in 2026 may still be the better way.

üìå Single-entry-point incident reporting is positive if also paired with streamlined reporting for businesses and sufficient resources for ENISA.

‚òùÔ∏è Finally, withdrawing the stalled CSAM proposal would signal seriousness about fixing, not doubling down on, bad ideas. ‚ùóÔ∏è

#KillTheChatControlForGood

#digital #data #digitalomnibus #GDPR #ChatControl #CSAM

posts.text:
Plans change. 

Last night's highly anticipated concert by Dubioza Kolektiv in Stockholm was supposed to be a trio, but one of the lads was, quite literally, on a plane from Japan. 

While we missed Nikola, me and Adi decided to go for it anyway.

And what a decision that turned out to be.

For those who don't know them, Dubioza Kolektiv is more than a band; they're a phenomenon. 

Hailing from the #Balkans, they fuse rock, hip-hop, electronica, and reggae into an irresistible sound, all while delivering a powerful message of social activism, unity, and political satire. 

They are the sound of positive resistance.

Their concert at F√•llan was a super-energetic, two-hour explosion of this ethos. 

They mixed new hits with old classics, and the crowd's energy was electric, a true collective experience. 

It was a live demonstration of their own lyrics: 

"Happiness is the only choice, when you don't have any other option."

When our original plan fell through, we chose to make the best of it, and we were rewarded. 

It was a potent reminder for both life and work: Focus on the energy you have, not the obstacles in your way. 

The momentum you build by moving forward is everything.

There's a unique feeling of combined pride and insight that comes from slicing raw data and watching a story emerge. 

Just yesterday, as I wrapped up the workweek with a custom SQL query in BigQuery against our cloud billing data, that familiar feeling hit me. 

It was a simple task, but the reward was immense, uncovering a perspective that wasn't possible through standard billing reports.

This has been a pattern throughout my career. 

My passion for data started back in 2006 at Nokia, armed with QlikView, SAP, and Excel, extrapolating mobile services usage data for the Nordics. 

The most rewarding part wasn't just building the dashboards; it was the weekly meeting with our sales and marketing teams, translating those data points into actionable insights on customer adoption and channel performance.

This thread continued at NetEnt and now at SEB. 

The tools have evolved, from MySQL and Splunk to Kibana and BigQuery, but the mission remains the same: to let quantitative data guide the way to qualified decisions. 

Data is useless if not communicated and acted upon.

As my career has progressed, the time for rolling up my sleeves and deep-diving into the data well has become more limited. 

But the need for this capability has only grown. 

That's why the most fulfilling part of my role now is transferring this passion to my teams. 

It's incredible to see team members, who were only waiting for the chance, light up as they move from assuming to knowing. 

We've built dashboards for uptake, onboarding, and operational performance that truly help us steer the ship.

"Without data, you're just another person with an opinion." - W. Edwards Deming

I'm a firm believer that a data-informed culture isn't just about the tools; it's about curiosity and the relentless pursuit of the 'why' behind the numbers.

#DataDriven #DataAnalytics #BigQuery #BusinessIntelligence #Leadership #ProductManagement #Cloud #DataStorytelling #SEB #SEBTech #SEBCloud
