posts.text:
üöÄ "Det dunkelt sagda √§r det dunkelt t√§nkta.‚Äù

(‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs vaguely said is vaguely thought.‚Äù)

This razor-sharp quote by poet Esaias Tegn√©r has been my North Star. 

Let me tell you why.  

In my senior years at the university, teaching intro math and programming lit a fire in me. 

Not just because I loved it (though I did), but because teaching forced me to truly understand.

No more skating by on surface-level knowledge. 

I had to dissect concepts I had learnt, rebuild them, and serve them to students with clarity - or fail. 

As Richard Feynman said, 

‚ÄúIf you can‚Äôt explain it simply, you don‚Äôt understand it well enough.‚Äù

That experience rewired my brain. 

Today, I‚Äôm hyper-aware of three things:  

1Ô∏è‚É£ What I know,
2Ô∏è‚É£ What I know I don‚Äôt know,  
3Ô∏è‚É£ And the vast universe of ‚Äúunknown unknowns‚Äù (shoutout to Donald Rumsfeld‚Äôs wisdom).  

Here‚Äôs the kicker: 

Pretending to know is a dead end.

I‚Äôve seen it backfire - in others, and in myself.

Socrates nailed it: 

‚ÄúTrue wisdom is knowing what you don‚Äôt know.‚Äù

Admitting gaps isn‚Äôt weakness - it‚Äôs the first step to growth.  

So, next time you‚Äôre tempted to bluff, ask: 

- Am I adding value or noise?

Clarity beats confidence theater. Always.  

üî• Stay curious. Stay humble. And never stop teaching yourself first.

#LifelongLearning #TeachingMindset #GrowthOverEgo #Feynman #Socrates #Tegner #Rumsfeld

üöÄ Why Your 3-Year Product Roadmap is a Fantasy (And What to Do Instead)

Let me tell you a story. 

Early in my PM career, I spent weeks crafting a beautiful 3-year roadmap. 

It had swimlanes, milestones, and outcomes mapped to the quarter. 

I presented it with pride. 

Fast forward 6 months: priorities shifted, stakeholders pivoted, and market dynamics flipped. 

That roadmap? 

A relic. 

A lesson learned: 

In tech, rigidity is the enemy of progress.

Product management is messy. 

For complex products with shifting dependencies, fluid markets, and ever-changing leadership priorities, expecting a crystal ball to plot exact timelines is laughable. 

Worse, it‚Äôs dangerous. 

Commit to dates too early, and you‚Äôll either burn out teams rushing to meet arbitrary deadlines or lose credibility when reality (inevitably) derails the plan.  

So here‚Äôs my antidote: Ditch the calendar. 

Think in time chunks - Now, Next, Later.

- NOW: What‚Äôs in flight today? What‚Äôs critical for the next 30-60 days? Focus on execution, blockers, and immediate outcomes.  

- NEXT: What‚Äôs likely in the next 3-6 months? High-confidence bets, validated by stakeholder alignment and user research. Keep it directional, not granular.  

- LATER: The vision. The North Star that guides decisions. No dates, just principles. Example: ‚ÄúSeamless omni-channel experience‚Äù or ‚ÄúAI-supported personalization at scale.‚Äù  

The reality bite? 

Stakeholders don‚Äôt need false certainty. They need clarity on why we‚Äôre building, not exactly when. 

A key stakeholder once told me, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt care if it takes 12 or 18 months - just show me we‚Äôre moving toward something that matters.‚Äù  

So, PMs: Stop rearranging Gantt charts. 

Start leading with vision, flexibility, and ruthless prioritization. 

Your team‚Äôs sanity (and your credibility) will thank you.  

#ProductManagement #Agile #Leadership #Roadmapping*

üö® Hot Take: Companies Don‚Äôt Have a Coordination Problem. They Have a Prioritization Problem.

Most companies aren‚Äôt drowning because they can‚Äôt coordinate. 

They‚Äôre drowning because they‚Äôre too afraid to say no. 

Internal politics. 

Fear of competitors. 

FOMO disguised as ‚Äúopportunity.‚Äù 

The result? A chaotic sprawl of half-baked projects, overwhelmed teams, and a culture where everything is urgent but nothing is critical.  

Instead of making hard choices, leaders default to hiring more ‚Äúcoordinators‚Äù to ‚Äúalign‚Äù the chaos. 

But here‚Äôs the irony: 

More coordinators = more meetings, more check-ins, more stress for already stressed-out teams. 

The vicious cycle spins faster.  

As Greg McKeown wrote in Essentialism: ‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt prioritize your life, someone else will.‚Äù

Companies that fail to ruthlessly prioritize, surrender their strategy to the loudest voice in the room.  

A Harvard Business Review study found that 94% of executives cite ‚Äúpoor prioritization‚Äù as the top barrier to strategic execution. 

Not lack of coordination. 

Not lack of talent. 

But the inability to say NO.

The fix? 

Stop hiring coordinators to paper over the problem. 

Start asking:  

‚úÖ What can we STOP doing?

‚úÖ What really moves the needle?

Clarity beats consensus.

Focus beats frenzy.  

Your teams aren‚Äôt stressed because they can‚Äôt coordinate. 

They‚Äôre stressed because you‚Äôre asking them to do everything. 

Break the cycle.  

üî• Drop the ‚Äúmaybe later.‚Äù 

Start with ‚Äúno, for now..‚Äù

#Leadership #Productivity #Strategy #BusinessGrowth #Essentialism #Priorities #coordination #meetings #reports #roadmaps #reporting

üöÄ Kubernetes & Cloud Agnosticism: Cutting Through the Hype

A while back, a colleague argued that deploying a third-party Kubernetes distro across public clouds is the ultimate solution to avoid vendor lock-in. 

While I agree Kubernetes is the de facto multicloud API, I pushed back on the rest. Here‚Äôs why:  

The Hidden Costs of "Agnostic" Kubernetes

Running a third-party K8s distro atop a cloud provider‚Äôs infrastructure would create unnecessary complexity without solving any real-world problems.  

- Costly Expertise: 
Configuring and maintaining standalone K8s demands rare (and expensive) skills. The CNCF‚Äôs 2023 survey found that 68% of organizations cite lack of expertise as a top barrier to Kubernetes adoption.

- Lost Cloud-Native Benefits: 
By sidestepping managed services (e.g., AWS EKS, GCP GKE, Azure AKS), you forfeit built-in monitoring, logging, and security tools - forcing teams to rebuild these from scratch.  

- Operational Overhead: 
Gartner notes that 60% of multicloud teams struggle with inconsistent tooling, leading to fragmented workflows and slower incident response.  

A Better Path: Own Your Code, Leverage the Cloud

True portability isn‚Äôt about abstracting everything. 

It‚Äôs about:  

1. Owning Your Codebase: Ensure that you know the ins and outs of your applications including any dependencies.  

2. Thin Kubernetes: Use cloud providers‚Äô managed K8s without unnecessary and quirky customizations. Treat it as a commodity layer.  

3. Embrace Cloud Ops Expertise: Let cloud providers handle scaling, upgrades, and security patching. Focus on what your team does best.  

As Kelsey Hightower said, ‚ÄúKubernetes is a platform for building platforms. It‚Äôs not the final destination.‚Äù

The goal isn‚Äôt to reinvent the wheel but to build applications that can adapt to any cloud - without sacrificing efficiency.  

The Bottom Line

Multicloud agility comes from application design, not infrastructure gymnastics. 

By keeping the cloud-specific glue to a minimum and maximizing code ownership, you retain flexibility and tap into the innovation (and budgets) of public clouds.  

What about you? How are you balancing portability and practicality?

#Kubernetes #CloudComputing #DevOps #Multicloud #TechStrategy

Today, I lined up for my tenth or so Kungsholmen Runt race. 

Let‚Äôs just say this one tested me like never before. 

Fresh off a lingering cold, with a cranky right knee protesting loudly, I stood at the start line thinking to myself, ‚ÄúWhy am I here?‚Äù

But when the gun fired, the pain faded. The only thing left was focus: Finish. Don‚Äôt embarrass yourself.

The cold faintly lingered in my lungs. But step by step, I pushed. 

And when I crossed the line in 43:37, it wasn‚Äôt about the time - it was about proving that resilience beats resistance.  

As Muhammad Ali said, ‚ÄúThe fight is won or lost far away from witnesses - behind the lines, in the gym, and out there on the road, long before I dance under those lights.‚Äù

This race was won in the quiet moments when doubt crept in‚Ä¶ and I chose to keep going.  

To anyone facing a hurdle (literal or metaphorical): 

Persistence is a superpower.

And sometimes, showing up - even when you‚Äôre not at 100% - is the bravest thing you can do.  

A huge shoutout to the running community for the energy that lifts us all. Every stride reminds me: Passion shared is passion multiplied.

posts.text:
When I was twelve, I was evacuated from wartime Sarajevo alongside my wounded father, mother, and younger sister. 

The events of that day are blurry in my memory, but one moment remains crystalline: a Canadian UN peacekeeper handing me a red maple leaf flag patch. 

Amid the uncertainty: Would we make it to the plane? Would my father get better? that small gesture became an anchor. 

I carried that patch for years, stitching it onto a summer jacket I eventually outgrew. But its symbolism never faded.  

That soldier likely saw a terrified child and offered what he had: a piece of his country‚Äôs identity. 

To him, it might have been a simple act of kindness. 

To me, it was a reminder that humanity persists even in darkness. 

Canada, to a war-scarred kid, became synonymous with compassion, dignity, and quiet strength.  

Today, as headlines dissect tensions between Canada and the U.S., I feel a deep unease.

The absurd idea of Canada‚Äôs maple leaf ‚Äúabsorbed‚Äù into another flag isn‚Äôt just political rhetoric - it‚Äôs a erasure of what that symbol represents. 

A nation built on multiculturalism, peacekeeping, and stewardship of the land. 

A neighbor whose global reputation is defined not by dominance, but by generosity: sharing its flag, its values, and its open hand with the world.  

Losing Canada‚Äôs distinct identity wouldn‚Äôt just diminish North America - it would impoverish the world. 

The U.S. would lose more than a trading partner; it would lose a friend who embodies what it means to lead with humility. 

Canada‚Äôs maple leaf isn‚Äôt just fabric. It‚Äôs a promise - one that gave a child in a warzone hope, and still reminds us that some nations choose to build bridges, not walls.  

To my Canadian friends: Your flag flies far beyond your borders. Never underestimate its power. üåçüçÅ  

#Canada #Peacekeeping #Gratitude #Leadership #InternationalRelations

(Photo: Paul Lowe)

posts.text:
Yesterday morning, as I prepared to attend Women In Tech Stockholm, I felt an unexpected wave of nerves - more butterflies than I‚Äôve ever had before a conference. 

Why? 

The reasons piled up: Some colleagues (both male and female) had asked, ‚ÄùWhat will you do there?‚Äù My wife and daughter wondered the same. And then there was my own fear: ‚ÄùWould I feel out of place?‚Äù

The only unwavering support came from my 12-year-old son and our incredible SEB #witswe2025 team.  

I went anyway.  

Walking in, I was immediately greeted by former female colleagues whose warmth eased my anxiety. 

As the day unfolded, I began to relax, connect, and feel at home. 

But one reality lingered: 

Of 3,000 attendees, only a small fraction were men. 

For me, this was a single day of being in the minority - a fleeting glimpse into an experience my female colleagues navigate every day in the tech industry, which is often dominated by men.  

It was profoundly humbling.

The discomfort of standing out, the subtle weight of being an ‚Äúoutsider,‚Äù the quiet effort to belong - these are not occasional challenges for women in tech. 

They‚Äôre constants. 

The conference wasn‚Äôt just a reminder of the gender gap; it was a mirror held up to my own biases and privileges.  

I left with two convictions:  

1. Empathy grows in unfamiliar soil.
üëâ Stepping into spaces where we‚Äôre underrepresented reshapes perspective.  

2. Allyship requires action.
üëâ It‚Äôs not enough to acknowledge inequality; we must actively listen, learn, and amplify marginalized voices.  

To the men in tech: Seek out experiences where you‚Äôre the minority. Sit with the discomfort. Let it teach you. 

Only then can we truly understand the change we need to drive - and become better allies in the process.  

Huge thanks to the Women In Tech Stockholm team for creating this amazing space filled with incredible people, energising topics and awesome mingle!

#WomenInTech #DiversityAndInclusion #Allyship #TechForGood #witswe2025 #SEBTech #sebcloud

üöÄ Application Modernization Isn‚Äôt Just About the Cloud ‚Äì Let‚Äôs Talk Code Ownership & Engineering Excellence!

We‚Äôve all heard the narrative: ‚ÄúMove to the cloud, and *poof* - your apps are modernized!‚Äù 

But here‚Äôs the truth: the cloud is an enabler, not a magic wand. 

While it offers out-of-box simplicity, scalability and flexibility, modernizing applications starts long before you even think about hosting options. 

Let‚Äôs cut through the hype.  

üõ†Ô∏è Modernization Begins with Code Ownership  

You can‚Äôt modernize what you don‚Äôt understand!

Deep knowledge of your codebase - its dependencies, quirks, and technical debt - is non-negotiable.

As Martin Fowler puts it: 

‚ÄúRefactoring is a disciplined technique for restructuring an existing body of code, altering its internal structure without changing its external behavior.‚Äù

Without this mastery, teams risk compounding complexity, not reducing it. 

Modernization demands ruthless prioritization: replacing obsolete libraries, decoupling monolithic architectures, and ensuring your app can run anywhere - whether on a Raspberry Pi, a VM, or the cloud.  

‚öôÔ∏è Engineering Practices > Infrastructure Choices  

Cloud migration without foundational engineering rigor is like building a mansion on sand. 

The real accelerators, for example?

- 12-Factor App Principles (Heroku): Decouple from environments, enable portability.  

- Test-Driven Development (TDD): Catch issues early, reduce fragility.  

- CI/CD Pipelines: Automate, iterate, and deploy with confidence.  

Gene Kim nails it: ‚ÄùThe goal is to amplify feedback loops so that teams can continuously improve their systems - and themselves.‚Äù

These practices create systems that are resilient, adaptable, and truly cloud-ready, regardless of where they‚Äôre hosted.  

‚òÅÔ∏è The Cloud Is Just the Icing, Not the Cake  

Yes, the cloud offers powerful and innovative tools: serverless, managed services, global scalability. 

But starting with infrastructure-first thinking often backfires. 

Gartner warns: 

‚ÄùThrough 2025, 70% of organizations that prioritize infrastructure modernization over application modernization will fail to meet their business goals.‚Äù

Rushing to the cloud without addressing code quality or architectural debt leads to soaring costs, vendor lock-in, and operational chaos. 

üîë The Takeaway? Modernize Upstream First  

1. Own Your Code: Audit, document, and refactor relentlessly.  

2. Embed Engineering Excellence: Adopt TDD, CI/CD, and modular design.  

3. ONLY THEN Choose Your Platform: Cloud, hybrid, or on-prem - your app will thrive.  

As software legend Joel Spolsky once said: ‚ÄùAll legacy code is somebody else‚Äôs mess. Until it‚Äôs yours.‚Äù

Modernization isn‚Äôt a destination - it‚Äôs a mindset. Let‚Äôs build systems that outlast the next tech trend! 

üí¨ Your turn: How are you balancing code ownership and cloud strategy?

#DevOps #CloudComputing #SoftwareEngineering #EngineeringExcellence #AppModernization #InfraModernization

posts.text:
We‚Äôre witnessing a high-stakes digital chicken race. 

While headlines fixate on tit-for-tat tariffs, Beijing is quietly executing a decadelong masterplan to achieve something far more strategic: tech independence.

The goal? Rewire the global supply chain so China‚Äôs digital future isn‚Äôt held hostage by foreign chips, software, or data rules.  

Here‚Äôs how they‚Äôre doing it:  

üá®üá≥ China‚Äôs Digital Sovereignty Blueprint

1Ô∏è‚É£ Policy Muscle üí™ 

- ‚ÄúMade in China 2025‚Äù: Billions poured into semiconductors, AI, and 5G to break foreign monopolies.  

- Data Localization Laws: Critical sectors like finance and energy must use domestic infrastructure and comply with strict cross-border data rules.  

- Phase-Out Deadlines: Foreign software (e.g., Microsoft, Oracle) to be replaced in government systems by 2027.  

2Ô∏è‚É£ Homegrown Tech Ecosystems 

- Hardware: Loongson CPUs, SMIC chips, and Huawei‚Äôs HarmonyOS challenge Intel, TSMC, and Android. 

- Cloud & Software: Alibaba Cloud and Tencent now dominate Asia-Pacific markets, displacing AWS and Azure.  

- Own Standards: BeiDou (China‚Äôs GPS alternative) and 5G patents aim to rewrite global tech rules.  

3Ô∏è‚É£ The Big Sticking Points

- Semiconductor Struggles: Despite state funding, China still imports 70% of high-end chips. US sanctions on ASML EUV machines are a major bottleneck.  

- Ecosystem Gaps: Replacing Windows/Android isn‚Äôt just about OSs ‚Äì it‚Äôs about rebuilding app stores, developer networks, and user trust.  

üí° Key Takeaways for Global Leaders

- Tech Decoupling is Expensive‚Ä¶ but possible with state-private alignment. China‚Äôs 5G and fintech leaps prove this.  

- Ecosystems > Individual Products: Success requires parallel investments in hardware, software, talent, and standards. 

- The Innovation Dilemma: Cutting foreign ties risks isolating domestic tech from global breakthroughs (e.g., AI, quantum).  

As Europe discusses #digitalsovereignty and India pushes for ‚ÄúAtmanirbhar‚Äù (self-reliance), China‚Äôs journey underscores a harsh truth: 

Digital sovereignty may not be optional. But at what cost?  

Your thoughts?

- Is self-sufficiency achievable without stifling innovation?  

- How should democracies balance own security and global collaboration?  

Let‚Äôs discuss! üëá  

#DigitalSovereignty #Geopolitics #TechStrategy #Innovation #ChinaTech  

(Sources: State Council policies, CSIS reports, Reuters, Caixin ‚Äì DM for links!)

Be the leader who lights the way, and be generous with the spotlight! 

Because when you grow your people, you grow everything. üöÄ

üö® "The cloud giveth, and the cloud taketh‚Ä¶ your budget, if you blink."üö®  

Yesterday, I re-learned a brutal #FinOps lesson: 

Never leave a high-cost compute instance running unattended. üí∏  

Here‚Äôs the drama:  

üî• Spun up an NVIDIA H100 80GB GPU ($$$) in my lab environment to test some Model Garden magic.  

üî• Got distracted. Left it running. Went about my day. Slept. üò¥  

üî• By 2:30 AM, costs had gone 500% OVER budget‚Ä¶  

But here‚Äôs the hero twist: Our guardrails auto-slammed the brakes, disconnecting billing the second thresholds were breached. 

No financial freefall. 

Just a cold, hard reminder:  

üëâ "Without guardrails, even experts become cautionary tales."

This wasn‚Äôt just a ‚Äúwhoops‚Äù moment - it was a live-fire test of why enterprises must have:  

‚úÖ Real-time cost monitoring

‚úÖ Auto-kill switches for runaway spend  

‚úÖ Cloud budgets tighter than a drum

Moral of the story?  

Trust, but verify. Build systems that save you from yourself.

#FinOps #CloudCostManagement #CloudEngineering #LessonLearned #BudgetGuardrails

Are You Beating a Dead Horse? Why Letting Go May Be the Smartest Move! 

We‚Äôve all been there - pouring time, money, and energy into a project, strategy, or relationship that‚Äôs clearly no longer working. 

The Dakota Indians had a simple yet elegant solution for this: 

‚ÄúWhen you discover you‚Äôre riding a dead horse, dismount.‚Äù

Yet, modern organizations often double down with absurd ‚Äúsolutions‚Äù like buying a stronger whip, forming committees, or - my personal favorite - providing additional funding and/or training to increase the dead horse‚Äôs performance.  

The Dead Horse Theory isn‚Äôt just funny - it‚Äôs painfully accurate.

The metaphor exposes our tendency to cling to sunk costs. 

Instead of cutting losses, we:  

- Throw resources at the problem. 
- Blame people.
- Mask reality with jargon. 

Why do we do this?

Fear of failure, bureaucratic inertia, or ego. 

But the cost is steep: wasted time, demoralized teams, and stagnation. 

As the list jokes, ‚Äùdeclaring that as the dead horse doesn‚Äôt have to be fed, it is less costly‚Äù doesn‚Äôt magically make it profitable - it just delays the inevitable.  

Dismounting takes courage however. 

Here‚Äôs how to do it: 

1. Acknowledge the horse is dead. Ask: ‚ÄúIf we started fresh, would we invest in this?‚Äù

2. Reward agility, not stubbornness. Celebrate teams that pivot, not just those who ‚Äúpersevere.‚Äù  

3. Kill the jargon. Call failure what it is! See it as a welcome chance to redirect efforts where they can give better returns.  

In innovation, the first step to progress isn‚Äôt moving faster - it‚Äôs stopping what doesn‚Äôt work. 

So, next time you‚Äôre tempted to hire a consultant to ride that dead horse, ask yourself: 

üëâ Is it time to dismount? üêé

Leadership isn‚Äôt about saving face. It‚Äôs about making smart exits - so you can find a horse that can take you places!

Agree? Share your ‚Äúdead horse‚Äù stories (we‚Äôve all got ‚Äôem) in the comments. üê¥üíÄ  

#Leadership #BusinessStrategy #Innovation #FailFast #SunkCostFallacy

posts.text:
Growing up in besieged Sarajevo during the 90s taught me the cost of violence. 

Many years afterwards, the sound of fireworks continued to tighten my chest - fireworks were a trigger, not a celebration. 

Sarajevo endured 1,425 days under siege. 

300 shells a day. 

3,777 on July 22, 1993 alone.

My family left on August 15 that year, part of a UN evacuation for the critically wounded - my father among them. 

Today, Sarajevo‚Äôs streets still bear ‚Äúroses‚Äù, granade shell scars filled with red resin marking where lives were lost.  

I am anti-war to my core. 

But I‚Äôve also learned this: 

üëâ When #authoritarianism rises, pacifism alone is not a strategy.

If #democracy, #freedom, and #humanrights are threatened, we must fight to protect them. 

Not because we seek conflict, but because surrender guarantees tyranny.  

Churchill said in a 1948 speech to the British House of Commons: 

‚ÄúThose who fail to learn from history are condemned to repeat it.‚Äù

Europe learned this the hard way in the 20th century. 

Now, as autocrats test our resolve again, we cannot afford nostalgia for #peace. 

Freedom has a price - vigilance, resilience, and yes, sometimes arms.  

To the free nations: #ReArm. 

Not out of fear, but defiance. 

Not to wage war, but to deter it. 

Because the only thing worse than preparing to fight is wishing you had.  

#ReArm #Europe üá™üá∫

Personal note: This post is raw, but so is the truth. Let‚Äôs build a world where roses like these never bloom again. üåπ

posts.text:
üö® Why Learn the Hard Way?

Tolstoy once wrote: ‚ÄùAll happy families are alike; every unhappy family is unhappy in its own way.‚Äù

The same applies to cloud migrations.

Successful ones follow similar patterns. But failures? Each is a unique cautionary tale. And that‚Äôs where the real lessons lie.  

Take UniSuper, a massive Australian fund. 

Their 2024 cloud meltdown (yes, an entire account was accidentally deleted) made headlines. But the real story started earlier.  

In 2023, they were racing toward a ‚Äúrecord-fast‚Äù cloud migration.

Their strategy? Familiarity over reinvention:  

- ‚úÖ ‚ÄùMinimal effort and disruption‚Ä¶ greater scale and agility.‚Äù

- ‚úÖ ‚ÄúTechnology the team is already used to‚Ä¶ no need to rebuild apps.‚Äù

- ‚úÖ ‚ÄúGet into the cloud quickly and safely.‚Äù

Sound smart? On paper, yes. 

But here‚Äôs the truth: Shortcuts don‚Äôt eliminate hard work - they just delay it. 

Even without the catastrophic deletion, their approach would‚Äôve backfired. 

Avoiding cloud-native architecture? 

Skipping app modernization? 

That debt always comes due. IT sprawl, hidden costs, scalability walls - it‚Äôs not if, but when. 

The takeaway?

Cloud migrations aren‚Äôt just about speed or sticking with what‚Äôs familiar. 

They‚Äôre about doing the foundational work - even when it‚Äôs painful.  

What‚Äôs your take? Have you seen ‚Äúshortcuts‚Äù blow up later?

#cloudmigration #digitaltransformation #techstrategy #learningfromfailure #cloudtransformation

P.S. If your team is quoting Tolstoy mid-migration, you might already be in trouble. üòÑ D.S.

posts.text:
üöÄ "Get the Right People on the Bus" ‚Äì A Leadership Lesson

Early in my engineering management career, I inherited a team focused on administrative work (alongside my platform engineering team focused on CI/CD tools and practices). 

One of the members on the new team quickly ‚Äúwarned‚Äù me: ‚ÄùMost people here just want a paycheck and to clock out early. Don‚Äôt expect much commitment or passion.‚Äù

My gut said otherwise. 

Sure, some resisted change - but indifferent? 

I refused to believe that. 

Later, I realized this ‚Äúadvice‚Äù was part of the play for the team member to paint themselves as the given team lead - an idea that had been planted by the prior manager. 

But the seed of doubt lingered: 

Could some truly be unmotivated?

I pushed hard. 

I rallied for change, emphasized purpose, and celebrated small wins. 

Yet, a few remained disengaged. 

The breakthrough came not from persuasion, but evolution. 

As some team members moved on, we recruited believers - people who thrived on ownership, change and operational excellence. 

A core formed, blending tenured and new members, all invested in the mission.  

Jim Collins nailed it: ‚ÄùGet the right people on the bus.‚Äù

Success wasn‚Äôt about forcing buy-in; it was about fostering a team that wanted to drive.  

Lesson learned: Cynicism often masks hidden agendas - or mismatched roles. 

As leaders, we don‚Äôt just manage people; we curate cultures. 

When you align purpose with the right talent, ‚Äúindifferent‚Äù teams transform into engines of impact.  

#Leadership #TeamBuilding #ChangeManagement #EngineeringLeadership #GrowthMindset

P.S. If you're wondering what was Marval and why it was being killed, it was an ITSM software that the team rallied around to replace for Jira that was a much better fit with the company and our ways of working. D.S.

P.P.S. A well deserved shoutout to the amazing NetEnt Change Management team that drove and made possible much needed change of the process, tooling and ways of working: Robert Hallam, Johanna B√§ckstr√∂m, Ann-Charlotte Ekstedt and Johanna Furborg! D.D.S.

Two months ago, I was honored to be asked to represent SEB at the Women in Tech (WIT) conference on April 23rd, both as a core team member and as an active participant in the event itself.  

SEB is not only a proud sponsor and partner of Women in Tech but also a role model through our commitment to career diversity, tech diversity, and people diversity - today and for generations to come.  

This important task also prompted me to reflect on my own female role models.  

Having spent my entire career in tech, I‚Äôve been fortunate to work alongside countless talented and innovative women. However, one woman in tech has inspired me more than any other: my mother.  

In her late thirties, after working in accounting for half her life, my mother decided to make a career change and dive into the world of computers. This was in the 1990s, and I vividly remember our discussions about whose turn it was to use the family PC.  

While my mom had a natural technical inclination and curiosity, I still recall the countless evenings she spent poring over course materials, determined to understand how everything worked.  

Her hard work, late nights, and dedication to learning eventually paid off. She went on to spend the rest of her career as a systems administrator and a computer teacher at an elementary school, retiring just a few years ago.  

Her relentless drive, her enduring thirst for learning about computers and technology, and her patience in experimenting and mastering new skills have left a lasting impression on me.  

I‚Äôm now truly excited for this year‚Äôs #WIT conference and the opportunity to reconnect with old colleagues and meet new ones. 

See you at Women in Tech 2025!

#womenintech #sebtech #seblife #lifeatseb

posts.text:
St. Patrick‚Äôs story of resilience, unity, and transformation holds powerful lessons for modern Europe. 

St. Patrick, born in Britain, was kidnapped at 16 and enslaved in Ireland. 

After escaping, he became a priest and returned to Ireland to spread Christianity. 

Using the shamrock to explain the Holy Trinity, he united people and built churches. 

His resilience, faith, and mission to bring people together made him Ireland‚Äôs patron saint. 

As a figure who bridged divides and turned adversity into opportunity, his legacy resonates deeply in a continent facing challenges.  

‚úÖ Resilience: Europe has weathered many crises and faces many more. Like St. Patrick, who turned his struggles into strength, Europe continues to adapt and rebuild.  

‚úÖ Unity: St. Patrick used the shamrock to explain unity in diversity - an important lesson for Europe‚Äôs multicultural societies. In a time of division, fostering connection is more important than ever.  

‚úÖ Transformation: Just as St. Patrick transformed Ireland, Europe is evolving by embracing sustainability, innovation, and inclusion to shape a better future.  

St. Patrick‚Äôs message? ‚ÄùTurn challenges into opportunities, and build bridges, not walls." 

Let us together carry that spirit forward.  

Happy St. Patrick‚Äôs Day!üçÄ 

#StPatricksDay #Europe #Resilience #Unity #Transformation

PS I hope you remembered to wear green today. As the tradition goes, wearing green on St. Patrick's Day is supposed to make you invisible to #leprechauns. They will pinch you as soon as you come upon their radar if you don't wear green! DS

üöÄ The CI/CD Conundrum: Why Are Only 40% of Applications Delivered Using CI/CD? ü§î

A few months ago, I had a fascinating conversation with Richard Seroter, and one statistic he shared has been living rent-free in my head ever since: 

ONLY 40% of applications globally are delivered to production using CI/CD.

Just think about it! 

As someone who‚Äôs been knee-deep in the continuous delivery space for over 9 years, this number surprised me. 

Back in 2016, my team and I took our first leap into CI/CD with a Java-based monolith running on a RedHat Linux VM. 

Before CI/CD, delivering our platform to hundreds of customers took us a year, give or take.

After CI/CD? 

We were shipping new versions several times a year. The difference was night and day.

But let‚Äôs rewind to the pre-CI/CD days for a moment. 

Remember manual deployments? 

Oh, the horror! I recall well our 47-step checklists (yes, 47!) to push an update to production. 

One missed step, and boom - our platform would go down faster than a Jenga tower in an earthquake. 

There was this one time when someone accidentally skipped step 23 (restarting the server), and we spent the next 2 hours troubleshooting why the application was ‚Äúacting weird.‚Äù Spoiler: it wasn‚Äôt the application; it was us. üòÖ

Or how about the time we deployed a critical hotfix at 2 a.m., only to realize we‚Äôd forgotten to include a configuration file? 

Picture the frantic Slack messages, groggy engineers, and a lot of coffee. 

It was like a bad sitcom episode, except no one was laughing.

CI/CD changed all that. 

It wasn‚Äôt just about speed; it was about reliability, repeatability, and sanity.

As Martin Fowler famously said, 

‚ÄùContinuous Delivery is a series of practices that reduce the friction of releasing software.‚Äù

And boy, did it reduce friction. 

Suddenly, deployments weren‚Äôt a white-knuckle, all-hands-on-deck affair. They were routine, predictable, and - dare I say it - boring. And that‚Äôs exactly how we wanted it.

So, why are only 40% of applications delivered using CI/CD? ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è 

Is it legacy systems holding us back? 

Fear of change? 

Lack of tooling? 

Whatever the reason, it‚Äôs clear there‚Äôs still a lot of room for improvement. 

If you‚Äôre part of the 60% still on the fence, let me tell you: the grass is greener on the CI/CD side. 

And if you‚Äôre already there, share your favorite CI/CD war stories in the comments.

#DevOps #CIDC #ContinuousDelivery #SoftwareEngineering #WarStories #TechHumor

Sixty plus years ago, Charles de Gaulle, the iconic French statesman and leader, had a clear vision for Europe. üá™üá∫

His vision emphasized national sovereignty, independence from superpowers, and a strong, united Europe.

"Europe must not be a vassal of either the United States or the Soviet Union. Europe must be itself."

"Europe is not a sum of nations, it is a union of nations.‚Äù

‚ÄùEurope must unite to defend its independence, its culture, and its way of life."
   
"The Franco-German friendship is the cornerstone of European unity."
   
"Europe must have its own defense, independent of NATO."

‚ÄùEurope is not a continent, it is a civilisation.‚Äù

"Europe must be a power capable of speaking with one voice and acting as a single entity."

His words echo all the more powerfully today, at this hard fork in the road for Europe. 

What future will we choose? 

One where we are in charge and in union with our peers, or one where we‚Äôre divided and unfree to make our own choices?

#europe #union #democracy #freedom #independence #european #unity

posts.text:
Adolf Hitler's dismantling of democracy in Germany occurred decisively after he was appointed Chancellor on January 30, 1933. 

Over the next 53 days, he and the Nazi Party used a combination of legal maneuvers, propaganda, intimidation, and violence to consolidate power. 

Below is a timeline of key events:

üëâ Jan 30, 1933: Hitler Appointed Chancellor

- President Paul von Hindenburg appoints Adolf Hitler as Chancellor of Germany, believing he can be controlled by conservative politicians.
- Hitler leads a coalition government, with the Nazis holding only a few key positions.

üëâ Feb 1, 1933: Reichstag Dissolved

- Hitler convinces Hindenburg to dissolve the Reichstag and call for new elections on March 5, 1933, aiming to secure a Nazi majority.

üëâ Feb 4, 1933: Decree for the Protection of the German People

- Hitler issues a decree restricting press freedom and public gatherings, targeting political opponents, especially communists and socialists.
- This allows the Nazis to suppress opposition voices and control the narrative.

üëâ Feb 27, 1933: Reichstag Fire

- The Reichstag building is set on fire. A Dutch communist, Marinus van der Lubbe, is arrested and blamed for the fire.
- Hitler uses the fire as a pretext to claim that Germany is under threat from a communist uprising.

üëâ Feb 28, 1933: Reichstag Fire Decree

- Hindenburg signs the "Decree for the Protection of the People and the State", which suspends civil liberties:
  - Freedom of speech, press, and assembly are abolished.
  - Warrants for arrests and searches are no longer required.
  - The decree allows the Nazis to arrest and detain political opponents, particularly communists, without trial.

üëâ Mar 5, 1933: Reichstag Elections

- The Nazi Party wins 43.9% of the vote, gaining 288 seats in the Reichstag but falling short of a majority.
- Hitler forms a coalition with the nationalist DNVP party, giving him a slim majority.
- The Nazis use intimidation, violence, and propaganda to influence the election results.

üëâ Mar 8-12, 1933: Seizure of State Governments

- Nazi officials take control of state governments across Germany, using force and coercion to replace elected officials with Nazi loyalists.
- This centralizes power under Hitler's regime.

üëâ Mar 23, 1933: Enabling Act (Erm√§chtigungsgesetz)

- The Reichstag passes the Enabling Act, which grants Hitler the power to enact laws without parliamentary approval.
- The act effectively ends democracy in Germany, allowing Hitler to rule by decree.
- The Nazis use intimidation and violence to ensure the act's passage, arresting communist deputies and pressuring others to vote in favor.

This 53-day period marks the rapid transformation of Germany from a fragile democracy to a totalitarian dictatorship under Hitler's rule. 

The Enabling Act, in particular, serves as the legal foundation for Nazi dictatorship, allowing Hitler to bypass the constitution and rule unchecked.

#historydoesntrepeatitselfbutitoftenrhymes

posts.text:
Leadership isn‚Äôt defined by the easy days. It‚Äôs defined by how you handle the hard ones. 

The moments that keep you up at night - letting people go, conducting salary reviews, giving feedback on behavior or performance - these are the moments that separate great leaders from the rest.  

Here‚Äôs the truth: there‚Äôs no way to dodge the hard stuff.

Avoiding tough conversations doesn‚Äôt make them disappear; it only makes things worse. 

People deserve clarity, honesty, and respect - whether you‚Äôre celebrating their wins or addressing their challenges.  

What I‚Äôve learned over the years:  

‚úÖ Positive feedback should be immediate and public. Celebrate wins as soon as they happen - it fuels motivation and builds trust.  

‚úÖ Negative feedback should be private and respectful. It‚Äôs not about tearing someone down; it‚Äôs about helping them grow.  

‚úÖ Every situation is different. People are unique, and their reactions will vary. Adaptability and empathy are key.  

As leaders, we have to lean into the discomfort. 

It‚Äôs not easy, but it‚Äôs necessary. 

As Brene Brown once said, ‚ÄúClear is kind. Unclear is unkind.‚Äù

And Simon Sinek reminds us that 

‚ÄúLeadership is not about being in charge. It‚Äôs about taking care of those in your charge.‚Äù

So, let‚Äôs commit to showing up - fully, honestly, and with compassion - even when it‚Äôs hard. 

Because that‚Äôs what great leadership is all about.  

What‚Äôs the hardest leadership lesson you‚Äôve learned?  

#Leadership #HardConversations #FeedbackCulture #EmpathyInLeadership #GrowthMindset

posts.text:
Meetings. The word alone sends shivers down the spine of even the most seasoned professional. 

They are the corporate world‚Äôs double-edged sword: a necessary evil for collaboration, yet often a black hole of productivity. 

As someone who is fairly caught up in meetings, I‚Äôve come to view them with a healthy dose of skepticism. 

If a meeting lacks a clear agenda, purpose, or actionable outcomes, it‚Äôs not a meeting - it‚Äôs a time-wasting ritual.

Let‚Äôs face it: not every problem requires a meeting. 

As Jason Fried, co-founder of Basecamp, once said, ‚ÄúMeetings are the graveyards of productivity.‚Äù

Too often, they are called out of habit, not necessity. 

The result? A room full of people nodding along, half-listening, while their to-do lists grow longer by the minute. 

And don‚Äôt even get me started on back-to-back meetings. These are the ultimate productivity killers, leaving no room for breathing, let alone thinking.

The human brain isn‚Äôt designed to switch contexts every 30 minutes. 

Cal Newport, author of ‚ÄúDeep Work‚Äù, argues that meaningful productivity requires uninterrupted focus. 

Back-to-back meetings fracture your day into tiny shards, leaving you exhausted but unaccomplished. 

You end up as a meeting zombie üßü - physically present but mentally checked out, with a mountain of action points and no time to tackle them.

So, how do we fight this meeting inflation? 

Start by asking the hard questions: ‚ÄúDoes this meeting need to happen? What‚Äôs the goal? What‚Äôs the agenda? What actions may come out of it?‚Äù 

If you can‚Äôt answer these, cancel the meeting. Period. 

Don‚Äôt let your calendar become a battleground of inefficiency.

Next, build slack into your day. 

Whether you call it thinking time, reflection time, or just plain old work time, it‚Äôs essential. 

Without it, you‚Äôre just a cog in the machine, grinding away without purpose. 

As Anne Lamott wisely put it, ‚ÄúAlmost everything will work again if you unplug it for a few minutes, including you.‚Äù 

Give yourself the space to recharge, prioritize, and actually get things done.

In the end, meetings should serve us, not the other way around. 

A life spent in meetings isn‚Äôt a life - it‚Äôs a slow descent into zombiehood. And no one wants to be a meeting zombie. üßü‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

Over the past year or so, I‚Äôve been on a mission to share my passion for an active lifestyle with my kids, beyond their regular karate and gymnastics routines. 

While my 13-year-old daughter occasionally joins in, it‚Äôs my 11-year-old (soon-to-be 12!) son who has truly embraced this journey with me.  

Every weekend, we spend 2x30-40 minutes together in our housing society gym. What started as playful monkeying around has now evolved into something much more meaningful. He‚Äôs begun to take it almost as seriously as I do! üí™  

Our routine is simple:  
- A warmup on the treadmill to get started.  
- Lifting free weights together.

What began as fun and games has turned into a commitment - at least for the first 30 minutes! üòÑ 

Watching him improve his technique week after week fills me with an incredible sense of pride and accomplishment.  

Beyond teaching him the basics of weightlifting, my real ambition is to create memories and spend quality time together. 

In fact these sessions are about more than just fitness; they‚Äôre about connection, growth, and shared goals.  

#Fitness #Parenting #QualityTime #Weightlifting #FamilyGoals #GrowthMindset

posts.text:
The Tito-Stalin Split of 1948 and the #Russian invasion of #Ukraine share some parallels, particularly in terms of power dynamics, national sovereignty, and resistance to external domination. 

üëâ #Struggle for #National #Sovereignty

- #Yugoslavia sought to maintain its independence from #Soviet control, asserting its right to pursue its own path to socialism. #Tito resisted Stalin's attempts to dictate Yugoslavia's domestic and foreign policies.
 
- Ukraine has similarly sought to assert its sovereignty and independence from Russian influence, particularly since the #Euromaidan #Revolution in 2014. Ukraine's desire to integrate with Western institutions has been a direct challenge to Russia's vision of a sphere of influence in the post-Soviet era.

üëâ #Resistance to #Hegemonic #Control

- #Stalin viewed Tito's independence as a threat to the unity of the communist bloc and his own authority as the leader of global communism. He attempted to undermine Tito through propaganda, espionage, and pressure on other Eastern Bloc countries to isolate Yugoslavia.

- Russia, under Vladimir #Putin, views Ukraine's pro-Western orientation as a threat to its own hegemony in the region. Russia has used a combination of military aggression (e.g., the annexation of Crimea in 2014 and the full-scale invasion in 2022), propaganda, and economic pressure to undermine Ukraine's independence.

üëâ #Ideological and #Cultural Dimensions

- Yugoslavia promoted a unique form of #socialism (e.g., workers' self-management) and a multi-ethnic, federal state structure. This stood in contrast to Stalin's rigid, centralized model of socialism and his emphasis on Soviet dominance.

- Ukraine's pursuit of democracy, European integration, and a distinct national identity contrasts sharply with Russia's authoritarian model and its claims of a shared "Russian world" (#Russkiy #Mir) that includes Ukraine. Ukraine's cultural and linguistic revival, particularly since 2014, has been a direct challenge to Russia's historical narrative of Ukraine as part of a greater Russian sphere.

üëâ #Propaganda and #Disinformation

- Stalin launched a propaganda campaign against Tito, accusing him of betraying socialism and being a "fascist" and "imperialist agent." This was an attempt to discredit Tito and justify Yugoslavia's isolation.

- Russia has used extensive propaganda and disinformation to portray Ukraine as a "fascist" state, particularly since the Euromaidan Revolution. This narrative has been used to justify Russian #aggression and undermine Ukraine's legitimacy on the global stage.

The parallels between the Tito-Stalin Split and the Russian invasion of Ukraine highlight recurring themes of national sovereignty, resistance to external domination, and the struggle for independence in the face of hegemonic powers. 

Both cases demonstrate the challenges smaller nations face when asserting their independence against larger, more powerful neighbors.

posts.text:
As I scroll through my LinkedIn feed, the calls for #European #digitalsovereignty are growing louder, and for good reasons. 

With shifting geopolitical dynamics, Europe must step up as a bastion of democratic values and technological autonomy. 

But how do we achieve digital sovereignty in practice? 

The path is neither simple nor quick, and it begins with a fundamental shift in how we approach technology - starting with conscious #dependencymanagement. 

At its core, digital sovereignty is about autonomy - the ability to control where and how our digital systems operate. But autonomy starts with visibility. 

If we don‚Äôt understand what goes into our applications - from libraries and binaries to APIs and external integrations - we‚Äôre effectively locked into the ecosystems where those applications run.  

Conscious dependency management means having full #visibility into every component of an application. It means knowing:  

- What #libraries and #frameworks are being used?

- Where are #binaries and #images sourced from?

- What external #APIs or #services are integrated?

- How do these dependencies impact the application‚Äôs #portability and #adaptability?

When you have this level of insight, you‚Äôre in a better position to modify, adapt, and migrate your applications as needed. 

However, dependency management is often seen as a back-end, technical concern - one that doesn‚Äôt directly impact revenue or customer experience.

As a result, many companies only address dependencies when they‚Äôre forced to - during a #migration, a #security breach, or a #compliance audit. 

By then, it‚Äôs often too late to make meaningful changes without significant cost and disruption.  

So, how do we shift this mindset and make dependency management a priority? 

Here are a few steps to consider:  

1. Educate and Advocate: 
Start by raising awareness about the importance of dependency management. Explain how it ties into broader goals like digital sovereignty, security, and #resilience.

2. Invest in Tools and Processes: 
Implement tools that provide visibility into application dependencies. From software composition analysis (SCA) to API #monitoring, there are solutions available to help you map out your application‚Äôs ecosystem.  

3. Embed Dependency Management into Development: 
Make dependency management a core part of your #softwaredevelopmentlifecycle (SDLC). Encourage developers to document dependencies, evaluate alternatives, and prioritize #opensource where possible.  

4. Foster a Culture of Ownership: Dependency management isn‚Äôt the sole responsibility of IT or security teams. It‚Äôs a #sharedresponsibility that requires buy-in from leadership, developers, and operations teams alike.  

Achieving digital sovereignty won‚Äôt happen overnight. It will require sustained effort, investment, and collaboration. 

But by starting with conscious dependency management, we can lay the groundwork for a more autonomous, resilient, and sovereign digital future.

posts.text:
In the modern world, identity is no longer tied to a single place, culture, or role. 

We are born in one corner of the globe, educated in another, and propelled by work, love, or sheer curiosity to yet another. 

This fluidity of identity isn‚Äôt a new phenomenon - it‚Äôs as old as human history itself. 

Take Marco Polo, for instance. Regardless if born in Venice or the Croatian island of Korƒçula, he ventured across continents, not just to trade goods but to exchange ideas, cultures, and stories. 

His journey wasn‚Äôt just about geography; it was about transformation.

As he once said, ‚ÄúI did not tell half of what I saw, for I knew I would not be believed.‚Äù

His words resonate deeply in today‚Äôs interconnected world. 

How many of us have felt the same? We move, we adapt, we grow, and sometimes our experiences feel too vast to articulate. 

Yet, it‚Äôs in this fluidity that we find our true strength.

Today, we are all Marco Polos in our own right. 

We‚Äôre born in one place, study in another, and build careers in yet another. We fall in love with people, cultures, and opportunities that take us far from our roots. And in doing so, we redefine what it means to belong.

Each of us carries a unique story, a mosaic of experiences that shapes our identity.

As one of my friends once told me, 

‚ÄúHome isn‚Äôt where you‚Äôre born; it‚Äôs where you become yourself.‚Äù

This sentiment captures the essence of our modern journeys. 

We are not defined by a single place or role but by the sum of our experiences.

Marco Polo‚Äôs story reminds us that adaptation is the key to thriving in a fluid world. 

He didn‚Äôt just survive his journey - he thrived by embracing the unknown. 

He learned new languages, built relationships across cultures, and found opportunity in the unfamiliar.

In today‚Äôs world, adaptability is our greatest asset. 

Whether it‚Äôs learning a new skill, navigating a career pivot, or building a life in a new country, our ability to adapt defines our success.

LinkedIn is the modern Silk Road - a platform where ideas, opportunities, and stories intersect. 

It‚Äôs where a professional in New York can collaborate with a startup in Nairobi, or where someone in Tokyo can find mentorship from an expert in Berlin. 

Our profiles may list our current roles, but our stories are so much richer.

So, to all the modern Marco Polos out there: your journey matters!

Your fluid identity is not a limitation - it‚Äôs your superpower! 

Share your story, embrace the unknown, and remember that every step you take adds to the richness of your narrative.

As I reflect on my own journey - born in one country, educated in another, having built a career that spans industries and borders - I‚Äôm reminded of the power of connection. 

Let‚Äôs continue to learn from each other and celebrate the beauty of our fluid identities.

What‚Äôs your Marco Polo story?

#identity #careerjourney #adaptibility #marcopolo #globalcitizen #growthmindset

PS. Image from outside of Polo house on Korƒçula.

Charter for a Competitive, Diverse, Dynamic, and Democratic European Union (in the style of the Agile Manifesto)

We are uncovering better ways of building a united and prosperous Europe. Through this work, we have come to value:

üá™üá∫Real Work over Paperwork

‚ÑπÔ∏è  While valuable documentation has its place, we prioritize tangible actions and results that directly benefit citizens and communities over excessive bureaucracy and administrative burdens.

üá™üá∫ Innovation over Regulation

‚ÑπÔ∏è Although regulation is necessary for stability and safety, we emphasize fostering an environment where creativity, experimentation, and innovation can thrive, driving progress and competitiveness in a rapidly changing world.

üá™üá∫ Diversity over Uniformity

‚ÑπÔ∏è  Recognizing the richness of our cultures, languages, and traditions, we celebrate diversity as a source of strength and resilience, rather than strive for homogeneity at the expense of individuality.

üá™üá∫ Collaboration over Centralization

‚ÑπÔ∏è While centralized coordination has its merits, we believe in empowering local governments, businesses, and citizens to collaborate freely, ensuring decisions are made closer to those they affect.

üá™üá∫ Adaptability over Rigidity

‚ÑπÔ∏è Though consistency is important, we prioritize flexibility and responsiveness to new challenges and opportunities, enabling the EU to evolve with the times.

üá™üá∫ Transparency over Secrecy
 
‚ÑπÔ∏è While confidentiality may be required in certain cases, we uphold transparency as a fundamental principle, ensuring accountability and trust between institutions and the people.

üá™üá∫ Citizen Engagement over Top-Down Decisions

Rather than imposing policies from above, we encourage active participation and dialogue with citizens, ensuring their voices shape the future of Europe.


That is, while there is value in the items on the right, we value the items on the left more. 

Together, these principles guide us toward creating a competitive, diverse, dynamic, and democratic European Union that serves all its members equitably and sustainably.

posts.text:
I don‚Äôt see eye to eye with all of Milton Friedman‚Äôs teachings but this one hits the nail on the head.

Milton Friedman‚Äôs boat analogy is one of his most famous explanations of #freetrade. 

He used it to illustrate the self-destructive nature of protectionism and why restricting trade harms a country‚Äôs own economy.

Imagine a country is like a boat. The boat has a hole in it, and water is leaking in. 

That hole represents tariffs, quotas, and protectionist policies that make trade inefficient and harm economic growth.

Now, suppose other countries also have boats with holes in them - meaning they, too, impose protectionist measures.

What should you do?

- A protectionist would argue: ‚ÄúOther boats have holes, so we should drill more holes in our own boat to be ‚Äòfair‚Äô and ‚Äòcompetitive‚Äô!‚Äù

- Friedman argues: ‚ÄúThe rational response is to plug the holes in your own boat and make it as seaworthy as possible - regardless of what other boats do!‚Äù

Friedman‚Äôs analogy explains that just because other countries impose tariffs and trade restrictions doesn‚Äôt mean your country should do the same. 

Retaliatory tariffs only hurt domestic consumers by making goods more expensive and less efficient. 

Instead of engaging in economic self-harm, a country should embrace free trade even if others don‚Äôt - because free trade benefits consumers and businesses alike.

In short, drilling more holes in your boat to match someone else‚Äôs isn‚Äôt strategy - it‚Äôs self-sabotage.

posts.text:
What skills should infrastructure engineers focus on in 2025?

I was asked this recently and my answer was:

	1.	Infrastructure as Code
	2.	CI/CD
	3.	Cloud

I think I surprised the person asking - #Cloud came third, and there was nothing about #AI!

Here‚Äôs my reasoning:

üëâ Infrastructure as Code (#IaC) ‚Äì Whether on-prem, hybrid, or fully cloud, treating infrastructure as code is non-negotiable. 

Engineers who master #Terraform, #Pulumi, or some other infrastructure coding language are setting themselves up for long-term success. 

üëâ CI/CD ‚Äì Infrastructure should be delivered just like application code - with automation, pipelines, and testing. 

Understanding build and deployment automation is key to reliability and speed.

üëâ Cloud ‚Äì Knowing AWS/GCP/Azure is important, but #engineering skills unlock cloud‚Äôs real value. 

Simply knowing which services exist doesn‚Äôt provide as much leverage as knowing how to provision, automate, and deploy effectively.

Now what about #AI?

AI/ML will shape infrastructure, but for now, AI is a tool, not a core competence for infrastructure engineers. 

AI-driven #automation (AIOps, cost optimization, auto-remediation) is worth exploring, but mastering engineering fundamentals first is the real differentiator.

If I could add more:

 üëâ Observability & Resilience ‚Äì Metrics, distributed tracing, and failure recovery patterns are key to reliability.

üëâ Security & Compliance as Code ‚Äì With growing regulations, embedding security directly into infrastructure workflows is critical.

These skills future-proof infrastructure engineers, no matter where technology trends go.

Is there anything you would add to the list?

Cloud providers love to talk about sustainability, but I have noticed that not all Cloud providers publish aligned, comparable carbon data across their regions and data centers. 

Right now, I reckon that two fairly simple metrics would bring increased transparency and set a common standard: 

- CFE% (Carbon-Free Energy Percentage) ‚Äì How much of a data center‚Äôs energy comes from clean sources?

- Grid Carbon Intensity (gCO2eq/kWh) ‚Äì How much CO‚ÇÇ is emitted per unit of electricity consumed?

With these two metrics, it becomes quite easy to calculate the actual impact of one's own cloud consumption. 

Still, in my experience, each provider reports differently, or doesn't disclose all data per respective region - making it impossible to make qualified comparisons. 

Is this simply because Cloud providers do not wish to be compared, or is there something else at play?

posts.text:
Just finished the audiobook ‚ÄúHow the Mighty Fall‚Äù by #Jim #Collins, and I found it quite insightful. 

Collins doesn‚Äôt just diagnose organizational failure; he provides concrete cues for how to detect and potentially reverse decline. 

The author outlines five stages of decline, describing how successful organizations falter and, in some cases, fail completely. 

Here‚Äôs a breakdown of the stages:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Hubris Born of Success

Success leads to overconfidence and arrogance. Leaders start to take their success for granted, assuming their strategies will always work.

Key signs:
- Ignoring the fundamentals that initially drove success.
- Believing the organization is ‚Äútoo big to fail.‚Äù
- Losing focus on the core mission or customers.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Undisciplined Pursuit of More

The organization overreaches, chasing growth, diversification, or success in areas outside its strengths.

Key signs:
- Expanding too quickly without strategic discipline.
- Pursuing growth at the expense of quality or long-term sustainability.
- Neglecting the core business or what the organization does best.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Denial of Risk and Peril

Leaders fail to recognize warning signs and dismiss evidence of risks or challenges. Success blinds them to emerging threats.

Key signs:
- Rationalizing bad results instead of addressing the root causes.
- Overconfidence in the organization‚Äôs ability to recover.
- Downplaying external shifts, such as market changes or competitor innovations.

4Ô∏è‚É£ Grasping for Salvation

In response to mounting problems, the organization takes desperate actions - often bold but unsustainable - in an attempt to quickly regain success.

Key signs:
- Focusing on quick fixes like flashy acquisitions or leadership overhauls.
- Abandoning disciplined strategies in favor of risky moves.
- Looking for a ‚Äúsilver bullet‚Äù solution rather than incremental progress.

5Ô∏è‚É£ Capitulation to Irrelevance or Death

The organization either becomes irrelevant in its market or collapses entirely. At this stage, recovery is unlikely or impossible.

Key signs:
- Loss of talent and customers.
- Bankruptcy, closure, or absorption by another company.
- An irreversible loss of purpose or competitive edge.

The five stages are both intuitive and obvious, although remarkably hard to see when one‚Äôs in the beginning or the middle of a stage.

Having seen the five stages play out first hand while I was at #Nokia, I can personally testify to their accuracy. 

It‚Äôs good to remember that decline is not inevitable or irreversible until the later stages. 

If identified and addressed early (stages 1 - 3), organizations can take corrective action to regain their footing. 

Leadership discipline, humility, and a focus on core strengths are essential to recovery.

‚ÄùHow the Mighty Fall‚Äù is a must-read for leaders who want to prevent organizational decline - or navigate their way out of it. 

The message is clear: 

Decline is not inevitable if you remain disciplined, humble, and focused on your core purpose.

It‚Äôs fascinating (and ironic) that these #Chinese LLMs themselves owe much to open-domain knowledge.

posts.text:
In today‚Äôs world of #disinformation, #polarisation, and #technological #change, the teachings of Hannah Arendt, a renowned 20th century political theorist, resonate more than ever. 

Her insights on power, democracy, and the human condition remind us of our shared responsibility in shaping a better future, for all, and not just a select few.

Here are a few timeless lessons from Arendt:

üëâ The Banality of Evil
Arendt observed how ordinary people, through thoughtlessness and blind obedience, can perpetuate atrocities. 

‚ÄúThe sad truth is that most evil is done by people who never make up their minds to be good or evil.‚Äù 

üëâ The Fragility of Democracy
In ‚ÄùThe Origins of Totalitarianism‚Äù, Arendt warned of how democracies can decay when trust in institutions collapses and apathy takes hold. 

‚ÄùBefore mass leaders seize the power to fit reality to their lies, their propaganda is marked by its extreme contempt for facts as such, for in their opinion fact depends entirely on the power of man who can fabricate it.‚Äù

üëâ The Importance of Plurality
Arendt celebrated the richness of human diversity, writing that ‚Äúhuman plurality, the basic condition of both action and speech, has the twofold character of equality and distinction. If men were not equal, they could neither understand each other, nor understand their predecessors, nor make plans for the future and foresee the needs of their successors.‚Äù

In a world divided by polarization, her teachings urge us to embrace diversity as a strength.

üëâ The Role of Truth in Politics
Arendt warned that when facts are undermined, public discourse becomes chaotic. 

‚ÄúThe ideal subject of totalitarian rule is not the convinced Nazi or the dedicated communist, but people for whom the distinction between fact and fiction‚Ä¶no longer exists.‚Äù 

Her words challenge us to defend truth in an age of disinformation.

üëâ The Need for Critical Thinking
Above all, Arendt believed that thoughtlessness is a dangerous state. 

‚ÄùEvil comes from a failure to think. It defies thought for as soon as thought tries to engage itself with evil and examine the premises and principles from which it originates, it is frustrated because it finds nothing there. That is the banality of evil.‚Äù 

In today‚Äôs fast-paced, algorithm-driven world, her call to ‚Äúthink what we are doing‚Äù reminds us to reflect deeply on our choices and their impact.

Arendt‚Äôs timeless ideas push us to engage meaningfully in our communities, safeguard democratic values, and remain vigilant against forces that threaten freedom and human dignity. 

#criticalthinking #democracy #HannahArendt #plurality #truth #facts #totalitarianism

posts.text:
Although I enjoy contemporary #games and #consoles as much as anyone who grew up with #videogames, there‚Äôs something truly special about #Xbox 360 #Kinect games. 

The magic lies in their simplicity - no #controllers, no #VR #headsets - just you, your body, and the game. 

It‚Äôs gaming in its purest form, and that‚Äôs why it holds a special place in my heart. 

What amazes me even more is that this technology, which feels so fresh and innovative, is now more than a decade old. 

In fact, Kinect debuted in 2010 and immediately set a #Guinness World Record as the fastest-selling consumer electronics device, surpassing even the iPhone, for some time at least.  

It was a groundbreaking innovation, using #motionsensors and #voicerecognition to let players become the controller - something that felt quite futuristic at the time. 

Despite its age, the Kinect experience hasn‚Äôt lost its charm. 

Quite frequently, I fire up my #Xbox360 #console and dive into games like Kinect Adventures or Kinect Sports with my soon-to-be-teenage kids. 

They love it just as much as I do and often invite their friends to play Kinect when they‚Äôre over. 

Watching them laugh, jump, and immerse themselves in the game is pure joy - and it‚Äôs proof that great gameplay transcends time and technology. 

The Xbox 360 itself was a cultural milestone in gaming history. 

Released in 2005, it set new standards for online gaming through Xbox Live and became the hub for an impressive lineup of titles. The Kinect added to that legacy by creating an entirely new way to play. 

It‚Äôs incredible how #gaming can bring generations together, whether it‚Äôs revisiting classics or exploring the latest tech. 

For me, the Kinect isn‚Äôt just about nostalgia - it‚Äôs about the timeless fun of playing together, controller-free. 

What are your favorite gaming memories, whether old or new? I‚Äôd love to hear about the consoles, games, or moments that have left a lasting impact on you and your family!

posts.text:
Early in my first engineering manager role, I had a 1:1 with a junior team member that left a lasting impression. He shared how overwhelmed he felt by the sheer number of acronyms our team used - myself included.

Sometimes, he‚Äôd stop and ask what an acronym stood for. Other times, he‚Äôd jot it down to ask later. But more often than not, he‚Äôd let it pass, unsure of its meaning, and wait for context to fill in the gaps.

It was a wake-up call. While we thought acronyms made us efficient - or perhaps made us sound more skilled - what they actually did was create a barrier for one of our team members to fully understand and contribute.

That day, I made a promise to myself: 

I‚Äôd always try to clarify acronyms if there was even the slightest chance someone in the room might not understand.

Sure, sometimes the explanation feels unnecessary. 

But other times, a nod, a smile, or even just a look of relief tells me it was worth it. It‚Äôs a small act that goes a long way toward fostering inclusion and making everyone feel part of the conversation.

As Albert Einstein once said:

‚ÄúIf you can‚Äôt explain it simply, you don‚Äôt understand it well enough.‚Äù

Language, like leadership, is meant to build bridges, not walls.

Have you had a similar moment where someone‚Äôs feedback helped you grow as a leader? I‚Äôd love to hear your story.

#Leadership #Inclusion #Communication #Teamwork

üëâ How do you objectively assess the operational maturity of an infrastructure team?‚ùì

There‚Äôs no single metric that perfectly reflects a team‚Äôs efficiency, reliability, and alignment with business objectives. 

However, several key metrics can provide strong indications of maturity. Some are well-known classics, while others are less common yet equally valuable:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Infrastructure as Code (IaC) Adoption
	‚Ä¢	Measures the proportion of infrastructure managed through code.
	‚Ä¢	Why it matters: Higher adoption ensures consistency, scalability, and reduced manual errors.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Automated Testing Coverage
	‚Ä¢	Evaluates how much of the infrastructure is tested automatically.
	‚Ä¢	Why it matters: Greater coverage catches issues early, leading to more reliable deployments.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Deployment Frequency
	‚Ä¢	Tracks how often the team releases new updates or features.
	‚Ä¢	Why it matters: High frequency signals agility and streamlined processes.

4Ô∏è‚É£ Mean Time to Recovery (MTTR)
	‚Ä¢	Measures the average time to restore services after an incident.
	‚Ä¢	Why it matters: Lower MTTR reflects robust incident response and recovery mechanisms.

5Ô∏è‚É£ Change Failure Rate
	‚Ä¢	Calculates the percentage of changes that result in failures requiring remediation.
	‚Ä¢	Why it matters: A low rate reflects effective change management and deployment quality.

6Ô∏è‚É£ Service Level Objectives (SLOs) Compliance
	‚Ä¢	Monitors adherence to defined performance and reliability targets.
	‚Ä¢	Why it matters: Consistent compliance demonstrates strong service management practices.

7Ô∏è‚É£ Incident Frequency and Severity
	‚Ä¢	Tracks the number and impact of incidents over time.
	‚Ä¢	Why it matters: A declining trend indicates improved stability and proactive issue management.

8Ô∏è‚É£ Operational Documentation Quality
	‚Ä¢	Assesses the comprehensiveness and accessibility of documentation.
	‚Ä¢	Why it matters: High-quality docs support efficient onboarding, troubleshooting, and scalability.

9Ô∏è‚É£ On-Call Metrics
	‚Ä¢	Evaluates the health and effectiveness of on-call practices, including response times and workload balance.
	‚Ä¢	Why it matters: Healthy on-call practices foster resilience and avoid burnout.

üîü Continuous Improvement Initiatives
	‚Ä¢	Monitors the implementation of lessons learned from post-incident reviews and proactive process enhancements.
	‚Ä¢	Why it matters: A commitment to continuous improvement shows operational excellence.

üëâ Did I miss any important metrics, or do these provide a fairly comprehensive reflection of an infrastructure team‚Äôs operational maturity? Let me know your thoughts!

Good to Great: Lessons Beyond Business

I recently finished Jim Collins‚Äô classic Good to Great, and it struck me how its principles extend far beyond business - they apply to #life, #leadership, and #personalgrowth.

The book explores why some companies transition from mediocrity to excellence while others fail to sustain greatness. 

Collins distills this into actionable principles, many of which resonate on a deeply personal level:

1. The #Hedgehog Concept
Great companies (and individuals) thrive at the intersection of three things: what they are deeply passionate about, what they can be the best at, and what drives their economic (or life) engine. This applies to personal purpose too - when we align our #skills, #passions, and #opportunities, we position ourselves for meaningful #growth.

2. Level 5 Leadership
#Humility combined with fierce #resolve defines great leaders. This principle isn‚Äôt just about leading companies - it‚Äôs about showing up in every aspect of life with a servant‚Äôs heart and a relentless commitment to #excellence.

3. First Who, Then What
Collins emphasizes getting the #rightpeople ‚Äúon the bus‚Äù before deciding the #direction. In life, this means surrounding yourself with people who share your values and uplift you, whether professionally or personally.

4. The #Flywheel Effect
Momentum builds from #consistent, #disciplined #effort. Success isn‚Äôt about one big leap; it‚Äôs about pushing the flywheel forward, one disciplined turn at a time. This idea encourages #patience and #persistence in achieving goals.

5. #Confront the Brutal #Facts
Greatness requires an unflinching commitment to #reality. Whether in #relationships, #careers, or personal #goals, honesty about challenges is the foundation of growth.

The brilliance of ‚ÄùGood to Great‚Äù lies in its simplicity and universality. 

It‚Äôs a roadmap not only for building great companies but for leading a life of purpose, discipline, and impact.
